div1.p: MORE WAYS THAN ONE, A COMEDY, AS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN COVENT GARDEN. By MRS. COWLEY.
LONDON: PRINTED BY J. DAVIES, CHANCERY-LANE, FOR T. EVANS, PATERNOSTER-ROW. MDCCLXXXIV.

lg.l: FLY, comic scenes! where distant Ganges laves
Hindostan's golden shores, with hallow'd waves;
Where palms gigantic rear their tufted heads,
And nature in colossal vegetation spreads,
Where rich ananas court the Indian's eye,
And groves of citrons fan the fev'rish sky,
Where rattling canes around the riv'lets play,
And the centennial aloe drinks the day!
In their deep shades bid Lucidorus smile,
His heavy sense of distant hours beguile.
Bid him not think, because I gaily write,
That heavy hours to him, to me, are light;
My native spirits, bounding from repose,
Bear me, unwilling, where Castalia flows.
I love to weep, love the soft feast of grief,
Court mournful thoughts, nor ever wish relief;—
Sadness I woo, yet still the phantom flies,
And joy seduces, whilst I ask for sighs.
But Hymen frowns, and joy no longer cheers,
Weeping, I sink—Thalia drinks my tears:
He tears my heart; she my rapt soul inspires;
He chills with grief; she fills me with her fires.
Thus, Lucidorus! pass my distant hours—
By turns subdued, the slave of rival powers;
And thus hath nature in my little frame
Still various been, and variously the same.
My heart so keenly feels, 'twere death to live,
Did not bright spirits its strong sense relieve.
Through THESE capricious, desultory, gay,
As though I felt not, glides th' unconscious day;
Through THIS I droop, I sadden, and complain,
Dragging, with pensive steps, life's length'ning chain.
In blithesome mood "More Ways than One" had birth,
Offspring of brilliant morns, and eves of mirth;
The laughing muse in sprightliest vein was by,
And "quips, and cranks," lay lurking in her eye.
O! may her spirit from its pages dart,
Dance o'er your nerves, and live within your heart!

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.stage: SPOKEN BY MR. BONNER, IN THE CHARACTER OF MERCURY.
Enter hastily from the upper end of the stage, as if just alighted.

lg.l: SOME eau de luce! Your fans, dear ladies, pray!
Strait from Parnassus—'tis a dev'lish way!
I might have strode our Pegasus's back,
But the poor devil's grown so mere a hack;
So often call'd upon—taught such strange paces,
That alter'd woefully, alack, his case is!
In former times, but once or twice a-year
The fiery steed was summon'd to appear;
Then in elegiac pas grave seen dancing,
Or in a comedy-curvet came prancing:
A tragedy each spring, a birth-day ode,
Was all his bus'ness on the Muse's road:
But now, such hurrying, helter-skelter work—
Each cart-horse moves with a genteeler jirk;
So—in a word, your patience not t' abuse,
We've sent our Pegasus to learn of Hughes.
My business here?—Plainly and flatly this—
To beg your Honours not to frown or hiss.
Thalia sent me, and it makes me sad,
For "entre nous, (says I) the thing is bad."
"Tut, fool!" the Muse replies—"this powder take,
"Long I've reserv'd it for a last dear stake—
"This powder take—dear Mercury, be quick"—
Here 'tis—a mighty spell, in this slim stick.
Scarce had she left me, when Melpomé came—
"Jove's Messenger, (says she) I'm in a flame!
"I know where Thal' has sent you—never sham it,
"But bribe 'em, God of Thieves! bribe 'em to damn it!"
"No, Madam, damn me, if I do!" I cry'd—
She aim'd a blow, I bow'd, and hither hied.
Now for my spell—
lg.stage: [Blows some powder out of his caduceus.
lg.l: There 'tis—I see it spread!
'Tis felt in ev'ry heart—in ev'ry head!
Now shall you fancy character and wit;
Taste in the boxes, humour in the pit.
You'll fancy, friends, that 'tis so droll and funny—
And you, that you've some substance for your money:
But should the charm dissolve e'er the play ends,
Oh! for Thalia's sake, be yet its friends!

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: Enter DAVID, preceded by a Lawyer' Clerk.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: HAS your master breakfasted?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Preakfasted?—Yes, Sir! Though we live at the court end of the town, we have prought up all our Welch customs. Our master hates Lonton manners, and Lonton laties. What is your pusiness, goot Sir!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: A business he will probably like, though it may concern a London lady. Acquaint him that the writings are engross'd, and that I have brought them, to fill up the blanks, and sign.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes, Sir;—please to sit, Sir [going]. The writings imposs'd, and the planks to—What was it, Sir? I must have it wort for wort, for my master is as exact as Shrewspury clock.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Acquaint him, friend, that the writings—the marriage articles, are ready. I have brought them from Counsellor Bouquet's, to insert the names, and sign and seal.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Now, in the fashionable course of things, how long may it be before I shall draw up the articles of separation for this young couple? It sometimes falls out for the good of the profession, that the happy pair see but one Christmas together. Nay, I have more than once in my time, engross'd the articles of marriage and separation with the same goose quill.

So, here comes the father of the bridegroom, to pore over the writings, I suppose. Come, good, wary Sir; if you don't quicken your motions, the young gentleman will excuse your cares;—every movement of that cane speaks a week's delay.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Tell Miss Archer to come to me by-and-by. So, Mr. Goose-quill—what—a—are they quite ready?

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Quite ready, Sir;—the names only are wanting.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, you may add the names in the next room; but I shan't sign 'till I have look'd your parchments cantiously over. No loop-holes for cavils—no expressions that will bear ingenious explanations. Defend me from the ingenuity of lawyers!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: You will find all clear, Sir. What are the names?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: That of the lady is Arabella Melville;—mine you know.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; it is Evergreen; but the gentleman's—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: The gentleman's!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—your son's—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My son's!!—my son's!!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I know it is Evergreen, junior; but the Christian name. I am sorry to be troublesome; John, Charles—Sir? Henry? George?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, thou pen-cutter! art thou come to insult me? My son! Evergreen, junior! Why, Sir, I am Evergreen, junior, minor, and major; there is but one Evergreen in the world, and I am he.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly crave pardon. Are you then the bridegroom?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Timothy Evergreen, Esquire, of Rook Hall, in the County of Salop. The bridegroom—aye, to be sure I am. Go, Mr. Feathertip, and leave the blanks as they are—I can fill them up.— [Exit Clerk.] Didst ever see such a puppy, David?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Never, Sir;—not to know that your Honour was the pride! I am sure one shan't see a livelier, puxomer pride in all—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Pride! Bridegroom—Taffy!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Got a mercy, Sir! Well, then, the pridegroom; and as for the pridegroomess, she is the sweetest, most innocent, modestest—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I know how to choose.—Did you tell my young plague, Miss Archer, to come to me?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: I tit inteet, Sir; and she bit me carry my Welch face town stairs again in a minute; for that it always made her preakfast sit uneasy.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, those women who have fine fortunes, and fine lovers, think they have a right to insult all the world.—She can't spare even me—me, who am her natural guardian, and fifteenth cousin.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Laws, Sir, she makes no more of you than if you were an olt woman, insteat of an antient shentleman.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: An antient gent—Oh! in point of family, you mean. Yes, yes,—but this is the last day of her triumph here; I would'nt have her another week in my house, if—

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Hush, Sir! here she comes;—and her eyes full of mischief.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Where is my guardian—Oh, my sweet guardian!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Sweet me, no sweets! I have sent five messages to your Ladyship this morning, ere I could have the honor of an interview.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My wise Guardian, then: it was to prepare you a present, my wise guardian, that I staid—a marriage present!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: A present, hey! What is it? what is it?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: You are to be married in a day or two, I find, to a young and beautiful girl—it is a present suited to such a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Let me see it!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Shut your eyes then.

div2.stage: [She goes behind him, and puts on a fool's cap with bells.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What the devil is it? a wedding nightcap?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, a night and day cap—'tis yours for ever.

div2.stage: [Holding his hands, whilst he shakes his head to get rid of it.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I'll teach thee to laugh, Taffy, in a moment. Let go my hands. Take it off, Taf! or I'll make thy sides shake to another tune.

div2.stage: [David snatches the cap, and runs off.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Now, are you not a most ungrateful guardian, to slight my gifts?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Miss Archer!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Young woman, you must attend to me.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Young man, I will.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I am, as you say, to be married in a day or two.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: David! bring back the cap.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I have told you these six months to provide yourself with another home;—you now have but six hours to do it in.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Because I would not have my young innocent wife infected by your manners.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My manners, Sir—What better fate could happen to her? Is she pretty?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: As a young cherub.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Then I'll teach her to captivate the whole town. Why, I, Sir—I am not so handsome—that is, not so extremely handsome; yet, with my manners, I am every where the object.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: But she shall be an object no where.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCH.
sp.p:
But she shall; I'll carry her with me all over the world; I'll teach her the equestrian bow
in Hyde Park, and how to dart through the croud in the coffee-room at the Opera. She shall learn—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: She shall learn, that, of all her mischievous hoity-toity sex, you are the last she is to know; and I'll dismiss every servant, that she may never hear your name.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I'll be her bridemaid, and, before she has been your wife six hours, give her more longings for laces, diamonds, feathers, and fops, than can be gratified in six years.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Huh!—h! Why the devil do you not marry yourself, and plague some other man. You have fools enough to choose from—Marry! you have my consent.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: But I want that of a much more important personage.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Whose?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My own. I shall not give up the right of making conquests yet;—when my time comes to retire from the scene of action, I'll pick out the most constant of my adorers, go gravely with him to church, drive soberly to the seat of his ancestors, grow a dutiful wise, study family receipts and made wines; and when I have the honor of seeing your young widow with her new husband, we'll drink to your memory in a cup of cowslip of my own brewing

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Seek new lodgings, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I shall not, indeed, Sir!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My house is my own, Madam!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
And my guardian is my own, Sir! [imitating.] Are you not my own dear, sweet guardian,
and are you not going to have a sweet wife, and to be a sweet simpleton, at the sweet age of sixty? Oh, my sweet, poor—poor, dear guardian! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Drink to my memory in wine of her own brewing!—I'll bribe some disbanded Ensign to carry her off, and make her glad to drink small beer of her own brewing.

div2.head: SCENE, Doctor FEELOVE's.
div2.stage: Enter SERVANT, looking at a list.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Let me see—one, two, three, four. Well, four new ones every morning, considering the season has unhappily proved so healthy, would do pretty well. I must call the doctor—'tis time he was out of his study,—oh, here he comes,—seemingly in a passion.

div2.stage: Enter FEELOVE from the Flat, with several printed Bills in his Hand.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are the nation about? What are the parliament about? Is this to be borne?—Here's a collection!—Every morning an inundation of new quacks. Here's a fellow cures the gout by injecting volatiles thro' your ear;—here's another freezes a fever by artificial snow, which he produces from the congealed perspiration of the patient;—and this, purifies the blood from all disorders, by the smell of mushroom juice, philosophically prepared. Why, what is to become of the regular practitioner, if these fellows are suffered to go on? What, I say, are the parliament about?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Considering, Sir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Considering! tax 'em! tax 'em!—The quacks shall be taxed. Have I been sent for to any new patients to-day?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; lady Juniper's dropsy has become troublesome again—she expects you at eleven. Mr. Calipash has a surfeit fever, and Mrs. Langrish hopes you'll call in the course of the morning.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Mr. Calipash a surfeit fever—hum! with the help of bark and aromatics, it may be prolonged three weeks, without injury to the patient.—As to old lady Juniper, frequent visits will be useful,—for in one tapping more she'll come to the dregs; and for my friend, Mrs. Langrish, if I can't prevail on her to prate less, she won't last me another spring.—That woman will talk two hours without breathing, to describe the effects of an emetic; and, if I did not lower her now and then by a gentle cathartic, she'd evaporate through the lingual organs, like air through a cracked bladder.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I had like to have forgot—Mr. Bellair is coming, Sir!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Coming! No, poor young fellow, he's going—he's going! there! there's the end of the life of a man of pleasure—it must be very unpleasant to be a man of pleasure. Nothing could ever prevail on me to be a man of pleasure.—Oh the temptations that I have withstood, from black eyes and grey, from tall and short!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I have often thought, Sir,—with submission—that the gentlemen of the wig go through more temptations than people are aware of.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, aye,—there are Josephs in the faculty, I can promise ye. Oh! the white hands that I have seen put out between the sarcenet curtains, with pulse disordered only by too much health! Oh the bright eyes that I have seen on snowy pillows! Oh the—but come, the faculty's great faculty is that of keeping secrets—I say no more. Did Mr. Bellair crawl up stairs last night?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: No, Sir; I could not persuade him, when he found Miss Arabella was alone.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, he abhors women now—the sight of a young woman throws him into a catalepsy. I have seen him faint only at the touch of Arabella's hand, when she has been chaffing his temples with spirits of hartshorn.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. I have sometimes thought he had been bit by some mad woman, and so had a sort of hydrophobia towards the sex. Here's somebody coming.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Ah! I see who it is—you may go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Good morning t'ye Doctor! Doctor Feelove, good morning! How are your pulse to day?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pho! a physician never thinks about his pulse, any more than a lawyer about his conscience; the pocket of the one, and the constitution of the other, both improve by the neglect.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Then why d'ye feel your patient's pulse?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: One can't do less for a guinea.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, here are the parchments, [taking them from his bosom] here they are! Nothing but names wanting, and sums.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Names, and sums, why are they wanting?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, that one may be clear. Your niece has thirty thousand pounds; and you agree that she shall be mine on paying you one-third for your consent.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: One half.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No,—one-third. I am sure ten thousand pounds for a simple aye is very well; we know a place, where they'd say aye for half the money.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Come, don't libel your betters, till you are poor, and want a pension. As to our affair, consider every thing. You know I boarded Arabella, with two sisters, at a village in Cornwall, who could teach her nothing but her sampler; the sole employment of her life, for sixteen years, has been her needle, with the occasional reliefs of making seed-cake, and stewing codlings.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I know all that—I know all that.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, you know, but you don't draw the inference. Let me tell you that a girl who can't write, who never heard of Point or Brussels; whose only game at cards is beggar my neighbour; and who thinks the Play-house, Ranelagh, and Vauxhall, the three great turnpikes to the devil, is a better fortune with fifteen, than a town bred miss with thirty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, well, 'tis in vain to argue. Here take the parchments,—fill up the blanks, and write your name. Shall I see my little Bell?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: To be sure. Call down my Niece. Tell her my Lord Penmanmeaur is here.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How shall we manage when she finds that I am not a lord, and that she will not be a ladyship.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
Pho! that's easily managed with such
a novice. Tell her that a peerage, like the parliament, lasts but seven years, and that your time is up. Here she comes! so, Arabella, here's his lordship.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My pretty Bell, my pretty Bell! why so sad?—on the verge of riding under your own coronet,—why so sad?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I am always sad, I think. They told me, when I left Cornwall, I was coming to London to be very happy, but indeed I was happier there. In the mornings I rambled in the woods, and used to listen to the sweet birds till they made me weep;—in the evenings I walk'd by moonlight.—Oh! how I love moonlight walks! with the distant village sounds dying on the ear, till, like the soft shades of the flowers, they could hardly be distinguish'd.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, you may have moon-light in London, when it is not foggy; and sounds of all sorts.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: But my uncle never suffers me to stir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, to be sure—not till you are married.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, nor then neither, without your husband.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Nor then neither! why they tell me, but I don't care about it, that when I am married I must pay visits, and receive company, and ride in Hyde Park, and be always in public, without once thinking of my husband.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [apart Doctor! five thousand must be added for that.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Why, how now, hussey!—who has been putting these wicked notions into your head?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why, sure they can't be wicked, for the Rector's wife and daughters over the way do so; and go out in fine carriages, and have cards on Sundays.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Hussey! hussey! that's a Bishop's family—a parish priest dared not be so wicked for his ears.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Come, doctor, don't be so harsh—my little pet will be a good girl. I have convinced her that she was made on purpose to be my wife; and that it will be the duty of my wife to hate gadding, and particularly to hate all young fellows.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No—you said particularly those with cockades and gorgets.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Did I?—then I was too slack. They are all the same—the gorgeted, the scarf'd, the broad bands, and the narrow bands; if they are young, you must hate them all—and if they presume to talk nonsense to you, make me your secret keeper, and then I shall be able to hold you up, as the exact model of a perfect wife.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, and, like other models, it will be very badly copied. But pray, mistress, in this pretty lesson of your's, where do you find any thing about your visitings, and gadding about, in the libertine stile you were just now speaking of?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, no;—no modest woman receives visits from any but relations; nor, amongst those, from none of a remoter degree than uncles and aunts.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What, not a Cousin?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Not if it's a male cousin.—Oh horrid! a male cousin in the family of a young married woman is a worse monster than a man-tiger.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: But Mr. Bellair is not my Cousin,—so I may let him come without any harm:—Oh! how I shall like to support his poor aching head on my bosom; and, when he is fainting, to give him cordials, and weep over him till he recovers.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are you saying, Arabella?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I was only conning my lesson, Sir; that part of it is so pretty, that, whenever I think on it, I sigh, and feel so melancholy!—and yet 'tis a melancholy sweeter than all the pleasure I have ever tasted.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, go, go! that's my pretty Bell; get it all into your head, and never fear but it will influence your actions.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I must leave ye, or my patients will be impatient.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, I shall see you again in the evening; meantime look over the parchments.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I will. Why, now I have been a fool; I have made the bargain more favourable on his side than I needed. I really believe he would have taken her with the ten thousand only. I'll try to start some difficulty in the business.—I hate to be over-reach'd.

div2.head: SCENE, CARLTON's

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
More Ways than One indeed! and your way is most singular! imported with you, I suppose, from Leyden.—Assume sickness to captivate a blooming
girl! such a way of love-making could never have occur'd but in a college.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My sickness was assumed not to captivate, but to get introduced to her. You have often heard that pity is sister to love, and I have proved it so, in the heart of the gentle Arabella.

div2.stage: Enter a Servant, speaking to BELLAIR.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Your servant has been here, Sir, to say that Doctor Feelove requests you not to call till one, as he is obliged to make a wide circuit this morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Very well. Bid him let my wrapping gown be ready, with my pale complexion, and all other necessaries. [Exit servant] I must have a wider gown; in that I am not sufficiently screen'd; who, but a Doctor, could believe that these limbs belong to a fellow in the last stage of an atrophy.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, they are so used to wonders, you may make them believe any thing; but have you never yet found a moment to convince the Lady, that you have as much health and assurance as any man in town?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never,—nor do I know that I yet wish it, for I should then lose the luxury of her tender assistances, the soft pressure of her hand, and the tear dropping from her blue eye on my cheek, whilst she believes me in a state of insensibility—How can I bear to give up all that?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Then to hear her sigh, and ask her uncle, in the teaderest accents, "if nothing can be done for me?" I swear, a direct avowal of her passion would not give me such transport. How charming! to witness nature's
genuine feelings in a beautiful girl, instead of those factitious ones impos'd by education.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Her mode of education has been strange, sure! do you find nothing repulsive in it?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Repulsive! quite the reverse—it has a thousand charms for me. Her mind is naturally so elegant and ingenuous, that the task of polishing it can be but slight, and that charming task will be mine! I shall be her enamour'd Abelard!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is it so very charming to be a school-master?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a phrase! [impatiently] To unite the characters of lover and instructor, seems to me the most interesting of human situations.
sp.l: "What joy to wind along the cool retreat,
"To stop, and gaze on Delia as I go;
"To mingle sweet discourse with kisses sweet,
"And teach my lovely scholar all I know!"
sp.p: So sung, you know, one of our first poets.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: One of our first poets is very welcome to have sung, or said it. But give me a woman whose soul is all inform'd, and alive to every enjoyment of taste and feeling! I would rather my wife should join in conversation with grace, than shrink from it, overpowered by her blushes; and that she should make the men afraid of her wit, rather than allure them by her simplicity.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You speak as though you knew such a woman?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Perhaps I may—but of that hereafter.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Hereafter be it then, for now I am impatient to be gone. I must practise an hour, before I
shall reduce my pipe to the shrill tone suited to my appearance;—you would not insure my life three days, if you should see me when metamorphosed.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nor your understanding for three hours, now that I know the cause of it—but adieu! in a week you'll be recover'd.

div2.head: SCENE Doctor FEELOVE's.
div2.stage: ARABELLA sitting at a Table, with Paper and Pencil.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: No, that won't do [taking up a slip of paper]—Yes it will—no! it is not half so soft and pretty. [retouches it] There now! that little touch at the corner of the mouth has made it clear another thing. Oh, how happy those ladies are that can draw!—if I could draw, I'd make his sweet face so white; and his eye should be just lifted up to me, as it is sometimes; and between his lips I would see a little bit of his white teeth, and—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Heyday! what is she about! [peeping] What now, Arabella! writing?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, no; you know I can't write—I wish I could.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
Wish you could! why? to enlarge your sphere of mischief? pity there's a goose-quill in the kingdom, except those in the hands of the faculty, the clergy, and the law;—though, as to the law, I believe, there would be no great harm, if their's were
taken away too. But what use, pray, would you make of a pen?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, I'd write—I'd write down a song that I have been making out of my own head, but I can't finish it, because I can't write. It begins—
sp.l: Soft are my gentle Jockey's looks,

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: "Lily pale his face."—Aye, that most young men can boast of—rosy cheeks are as scarce now in England, as rose bushes in Scotland. Let me see that paper—what's this? a flower pot?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No, it's Jockey. [very artlesly.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Jockey! why thou hast a good pretty notion, girl, enough!—some fancy there—it might take a man a good while to explain it. But come, [throwing down the paper, which she picks up, and puts in her bosom.] I want to talk to you a little. Here will be the poor young man presently—Mr. Bellair.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear, will be? [joyfully.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Now you know he's dying.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Is he. [sadly.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Therefore we must make hay while the sun shines.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: The sun won't shine, when he dies. [aside.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: He has a good fortune, and neither chick nor child. He must leave it to somebody you know, and most likely it will be to those who are most kind to him; now I would have you shew every kind of decent civility to him, that a modest young woman may shew.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
I am sure I always do. I would lay down my life to bate his pains; sometimes they are very bad,
and then he grasps my hand so hard!—but I am not angry with him.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, to be sure; he is sick, poor man—if he was well 'twould be quite another thing—never let a man in health press your hand. But, as I was saying, I have no doubt but his gratitude will secure us some acknowledgement at his death.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, dear uncle! you had better secure an acknowledgement for saving his life.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, but when people's lives are saved, they seldom think of an acknowledgement;—if you can get into a sick man's will, 'tis safer to let him go.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mr. Bellair is coming up, Sir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Oh, let me assist him. [runs out] Stay, good Sir!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, dear, how weak he is! [looking through the wing.] But I declare he is not so pale—no not half so pale as he was. Oh! how I should love my uncle if he would recover him—I'd give all I have in the world!

div2.stage: Enter BELLAIR, supported by FEELOVE, and the SERVANT.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Lean on me, good Mr. Bellair, lean harder! come, think me your nurse, as well as your Doctor—you know we rank with old women.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [Panting] You, are kind—hooh! very kind. Your stairs—hooh! have exhausted too much of my wasting breath.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all our breaths are wasting; but come, take courage—you may have more years before ye, than I have yet, perhaps.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, I guess I may; or Nature will play me a slippery trick. [aside.] Pray support me to that sopha. [advances a step or two, then stops short.] That young woman there again! Oh, Doctor! do you not know how baneful to me, is the sight of a young woman?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, how can he hate me so? it will break my heart. [aside.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, my niece is useful in the room; you are sometimes apt to be faintish, and maid-servants are so unhandy—But if she offends you, she shall go.—Go, Arabella.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Well, I can stay at the door, and see him through the crevice—Sure that can't offend him!— [pensively.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, let her stay—let her stay! Going out of the world, as I am, it is my duty to conquer aversions. I will even let her sit by me—Sit down, young lady!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Where are your drops, Arry?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Here they be.

div2.stage: [She takes them from her pocket; he seizes the bottle and her hand together.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Don't take too much of 'em, Sir—don't keep them too long at your nose.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, they revive me beyond expression!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, they are very good drops. Dear, how tight he holds my hand! [aside.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My spirits are very low; and I have odd fancies, Doctor—very odd fancies!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but you should always oppose odd fancies. I knew an old lady, who fancied herself pursued by Death—She swore he should not have her, and actually contended with the phantasm so long, that she vanquished him. That very obstinacy which sent three husbands out of the world, kept her in it, contrary to the predictions of the wisest heads in Warwicklane.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But I have a stranger fancy than that, Doctor.—I have a fancy that I shall live, and be some day or other a hale, stout young fellow.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: [aside.] That's a strange fancy, indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And that many beings may yet owe life to me.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I have no doubt of it, Sir . . . . . Beings of the reptile kind.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir, here is a gentlewoman, very earnest to consult you.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I'll be with her in a moment. Will you give me leave?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Go, go, good Doctor, I will try to recover myself, to tell you my new symptoms, when you return.—But pray don't hurry the gentlewoman.

div2.stage: [Exit FEELOVE. BELLAIR turns and gazes on ARABELLA.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, angel!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Is he going to pray? how fiery his eyes look! [aside.] . . . . . . Pray, Sir, quiet yourself; rest your head a little on me—I fancy it is in pain.

div2.stage: [He rests his head on her shoulder, with his arm round her.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Epicures and voluptuaries!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: He talks Latin! they say people do so, when they are possess'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, this is too much! [lifting his head.] I will declare myself at once.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear Sir, if you have any sins upon your mind, the sooner you declare them the better—it may make your conscience easy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, I will declare—Oh, most enchanting—

div2.stage: [drops on one knee; Feelove enters, and he lets himself fall on the floor.]

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Bless me, he is fainting!—aye, he is far gone indeed, poor man!—Very odd! [taking his hand.] His pulse is good, though he is so bad.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: When he fell he was going to declare some crime to me—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Some crime!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, and it seemed to overpower his conscience so, the moment he began to speak, that he could not bear it.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, he has been but bad, I doubt, but now he pays for all. Come, Sir, cheer ye, cheer ye! [helping him up.] I won't leave ye again; I'll sit by ye, if its an hour;—the very sight of a Doctor is better, sometimes, than physic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are very kind! but I believe I shall not be the better for you now. In the afternoon, if you'll permit me, I shall call again.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I'll go to you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Not for the world!—I give you too much
trouble. The air of this part of the town, so near the Park, revives me—Permit me to come as often as I can; I hope I shall not be long in this sad way. Pray, Doctor!

div2.stage: [putting a bank note in his hand.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, it is needless.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The young lady's drops are very good. About six I'll be here again—you'll let her be in the way.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That she shall. Come, Sir, lean on me.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, how he looks at me! it thrills my bosom through and through! Sure he can have no very great crime on his mind—I am sure he never can have been wicked—I'll endeavour to comfort him when he comes again. Meantime, I'll go into my own room, and try to finish this. [taking the paper from her bosom.] I think I can make it look a little as he did just now,—and then—then, if he dies— [dropping a tear.] I can look at this, and think of him!

div2.head: SCENE, the Horse Guards.
div2.stage: Enter CARLTON, followed by BELLAIR in a Chair.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [to the Chairman.] Stop—stop! Carlton!— [gets out of the chair, and throws in his gown.] There! carry it home, and call for me at six.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, oh! what return'd from the Doctor's?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This moment left the house;—this moment left—Oh, Carlton!—I shall be there again at six—My time will hang on my hands till then—how shall I kill the heavy hours?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
If you really want to murder them, go
home, and send for a dozen of the reforming reports: if you want only to forget them, go with me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: To call on Sir Marvel Mushroom. I pay him a visit once in six months, stay six minutes; and laugh, after I have left him, six hours.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Who the devil is this Sir Marvel, who is such a specific for ennui?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Been in London a month, and not know Sir Marvel! Why, Sir Marvel was the other day a grocer, or an ironmonger, or a cheesemonger, I don't remember which—near one of the city gates, I don't remember where.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What is he now?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Now! a man of figure, Sir—a man of expence. To be seen every morning in Hyde Park, on a little Galloway, followed by two servants on a brace of hunters. Every noon in a phaeton, making the circuit of St. James's-street, Pall Mall, and the Hay Market; and every night, in every place where a ticket or effrontery can admit him.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, but where's the peculiarity of all this?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, all that's nothing—the captivating part of the Knight is to come. At the youthful age of forty some relation left him a large estate:—He threw off his apron, drove to his domains in a post chaise and six, roasted bullocks, broach'd hogsheads, &c. &c. was next year sheriff for the county, and carried up an address—This accounts for his title.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
His Honour now found it necessary to read, on the penalty of being silent wherever he went—to
which his loquacity could not submit. He accordingly buys every author on every subject; peruses poetry, tactics, philosophy, botany, cookery, agriculture; and, to shew that he can read, is for ever quoting.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tiresome enough!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Not at all—as he manages, 'tis most pleasant; for beginning to read so late in life, with the advantage of a very bad memory, he makes the happiest mistakes imaginable. His head contains an olio of arts and sciences, so mingled and confused that he constantly speaks of one thing for another; and if Boyle or Clarendon are mention'd, ten to one but he'll give ye an old catch as a specimen of their talents.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: His French valet assists in furnishing the inside of his head, as well as to frize the out, and always gives his master the theme for the day.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Precious! this fellow must be excellent to kill time with—let us go directly.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: With all my heart—he receives a new acquaintance as eagerly as a new book; and whether you are in calf-skin or morocco, it will make no difference to Sir Marvel.

div2.head: SCENE, a Dressing Room.
div2.stage: [SIR MARVEL at his toilet, attended by LE GOUT, who is powdering his hair with a puff.]

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Depechez, monsieur—depechez! I am impatient.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p:
Ah, monsieur! de Inglis be tous jours so, and for dat reason dey will never do credit to dere valets. A French general spend as much time in taking
de powder in his hair, as in direction de powder to his enemy; and would rader live, dan be found dead in the field of battle ill dress.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, but now, you know, monsieur, the French are going to follow us—we are all the go in Paris. Next war I dare say your generals will head their armies in buckskin, and bobwigs; and if they are found dead on the field of battle, it will be with British balls in their bodies. (starting up) Have done! you have been as long raising the siege of that curl, as the Goths were in taking Cuba.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Nay den, monsieur, I vill ave done; but pardon me, monsieur! it does use me very ill; I vill live vid no master who so disgrace me.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Disgrace you!

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Oui, sans doute, de disgrace be mine. De quality will not say of you—"Oh, what Burgeois be dat! ah, mon Dieu, quelle bete!" dey will say who drest dat man? he be as mal adroit as a Flemish boor—send him a new valet, he be dress by a Dutch barber." My reputation be concern'd, monsieur.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why now you know, Le Gout, I take great care of your reputation, and form myself entirely on your documents. You have liv'd so long with dukes and lords, and noble cricketers, and gentlemen chessplayers, that you know the dash of high life exactly; and if I had a son, I would prefer you to any French governor in London.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p:
Oh, as to dat, monsieur, I would not be French governor to any ting. Running about after little master—sitting behind him at de play, and vid my
back to de horses in de vis-a-vis, and be at de bottom of de table when de chaplain ave leave of absence;—no, no, some French governors dat I know ave taken up de powder puff again, and prefer dere original occupation of valet, to de pleasure of whipping master for von hundred a year, and being tied to his jacket, like de keys to de housekeeper's girdle.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Well but, monsieur, have you thought of a subject for me to day—You can't conceive how brilliant I was at Mrs. Flanconade's yesterday. She thought to pose me once, and interrupted me with (speaking in a thick voice.) "Pray, Sir Marvel Mushroom, at what time was the Roman republic in it's glory?" Very good, ma'am, says I—very good! as tho' all the world did not know the republic was in it's greatest lustre when Alexander the Great was king at Rome—ha, ha, ha! No conceiving how it was enjoy'd—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Dere monsieur! dere! I be disgrace again. Why Alexander was never king at Rome, he was king of de Turcs.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You are right, you are right, Monsieur. The dog is clearly wrong, but I dare not contradict him.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A gentleman, whose name is Pearlash, is below, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Pearlash—Pearlash! oh, I remember; I knew him last year at Brighton. The son of a soap boiler, Le Gout. What the devil does he want?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: He only sent up his name, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: His name! why surely he does not put himself on a visiting foot. Tell him, I am engag'd at present—some other time—

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Oh, wrong, Monsieur!—pardon me, quite wrong!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why! should I receive him?

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Sans doute—receive every body. De great people make all dere power dat way. In Grosvenor-square, a citizen fend his name to a lord;—de lord shrug his shoulders—"damn de greasy soap boiler—send him up!" He fly to receive him, catches his hand—"My dear Mr. Pearlash, how I am oblige for dis honeur!—where have you been dis age? can I do any ting for you?—make use of me—give me de happiness to serve you!"

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Do they condescend so much?

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Condescend!—pshaw! dat idea is banish de world—dere is no condescension. De canaille is de fountain of riches, derefore de lords treat dem vid respect, and tell dem of dere majesty: in return, de Canaille, bursting vid vanity and gratitude, let de Lords drain dere purses, and so bote sides rest satisfie.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Enough! Lead the way. [to the Servant.] Le Gout, follow. I'll snatch his hand, and outdo a duke in the warmth of my embraces.

div2.stage: Enter CARLTON and BELLAIR, with another Servant.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel is just gone down to some company, Sir.—I'll inform him that you are here.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Was not that the lovely Bab Archer, you bowed to, as we came in?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It was Miss Archer; but you don't think her handsome?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Critically so—perhaps not; but she is more—she is captivating! Her voice is melody; and there is elegant mind in every motion.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Elegant mind, do you call it? I am sure her's is a most insolent one.—I knew her abroad; and this woman, who in your opinion is made up of melody, sweetness, and witchery, is the most perverse, the most capricious, the most proud, the—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Tut! tut! that is to say, you have been her slave, and a neglected one.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Faith, there is hardly a man of your acquaintance who will not subscribe to my opinion of her.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: The strongest proof of her charms, and of her power. I adore her for being hated by all the men who have had the presumption to sigh for her. There is a degree of impurity in a woman who smiles on, and listens to, all who choose to make love to her. When I marry, my wife must bring me an ear as unessayed as her heart; and the first whispers of love that reach her, must be from my lips.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, carry your whispers to Miss Archer, kneel, sigh, weep, and—be despised!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: At your conceiving that, with a woman of her character, I should pursue so beaten a track. No, no; I have resolv'd to woo her, but it shall be by an appearance of indifference. I'll set her heart in a blaze by my coldness, and conquer her with slights.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Why your way of love making is more singular than mine; but as to its success, I should as soon
believe the floating batteries had more effectually been attack'd by snow balls, than Elliot's red hot bullets.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A flaming allusion!—But here comes our Knight. [Enter MARVEL and LE GOUT.] My dear Sir Marvel, Mr. Bellair begs to be known to you.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: My dear Sir, I do not deserve so great an honour. [Embracing Bellair] Can I do any thing for you?—make use of me—give me the happiness to serve you.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Monsieur—Monsieur! dis is not de way to treat gentlemen. You must embrace, and make offers of service, only to de canaille.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Enough! did you come from the country, Mr. Bellair?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: From Leyden.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Leyden! you came from Leyden—ah! I remember, that's the place where they are so famous for lead mines.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is no standing this. [to Carlton.] You have good paintings, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, I flatter myself I have taste that way. We have moderns who pretend to paint—ha, ha!—save us from modern painters!—the antique is the thing! Now, for a portrait painter, there's nobody like that little droll fellow, Erasmus; he gave us flesh and blood to the life!—But for a cabinet piece, give me a Dutch Fair by Scipio Africanus. What is he laughing at? he behaves very oddly!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You must excuse him—unhappily ignorant—has read nothing.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
Indeed! I'll offer him my library. My
dear Sir, you'll pardon me; but one can make no figure without reading. In such a place as Leyden, you can have had no opportunities—My library is at your service.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You do me a most particular favour, Sir Marvel. Well chosen, I am sure it must be.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, as to that—yes, yes, Sir—aye, Mr. Carlton, you have seen my library. All the poets from Mecaenas to Shaftsbury. All the dramatic writers of name—including Shakespear, Lycurgus, and Pliny.—Read well, Sir; and after you have read, begin to write.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Write!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, yes; one is not finish'd without it—every body writes. One cannot put one's head into company without meeting half a dozen ode-writing misses, and matrons who compose essays—but satire is my forte.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What then you write, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Trifles! trifles! There is a thing of mine in the papers to-day. You know, for every body knows, Miss Archer?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Doubtless.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You know she is the most haughty, affected creature living; and to-day I gave her in doggerel—mark that—in doggerel; heroic verse would have been too dignified for the subject. There she is, in the poet's corner, at full length.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Satirize Miss Archer!—surely you have not dared.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes I have. Why not satirize Miss Archer? I satirize myself sometimes, and answer it again the next day.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: By Heaven! on reflection, it pleases me.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Besides, to tell you the truth, there is another reason—Now I shall surprise ye, I know;—I hardly expect ye to believe me—but—in short, she has actually refused me!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Refused you! Nay then, Carlton, you may as well give it up—You'll hardly expect to succeed where Sir Marvel has failed.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I don't know that—I don't know that; those capricious women generally choose the worst—You know the proverb—dainty dogs.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Delicate! So 'tis revenge, then—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, revenge—But I still continue to visit her in a friendly way; for she's fashionable, and one finds the first dash there: Besides, I have such good-nature and generosity about me, that I never can be out of humour with people to their faces.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: In course, you don't mean to acknowledge your satire. But is it very severe?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, tears her like a bramble bush.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Then do me the favour to give me for the author.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Are you serious?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Most particularly so:—In short, I want to be introduced to her, and I know no better way.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tell her he is dying for her—that's a better way.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Yes, to be made a fool. Will you oblige me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: To be sure—Gad, I shall like such a screen! for I have had the terror of her fingers before my eyes.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Go, then, this instant, my dear Sir Marvel; not a moment is to be lost! Come, Bellair. Let nothing tempt you betray that you are the poet.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Never fear! I am not a goose, to betray the Capitol.

div2.stage: Enter Miss JUVENILE, and a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Miss JUVENILE.
sp.p: TELL Miss Archer I can't stay a minute, I have only brought a newspaper to shew her. [exit Serv.] Lud! lud! how this will gall her! I never read such a piece of abuse in my life.—I wonder how the author got it in! I have wrote twenty pretty things of this sort myself; but some wise, grave editor or other, always cropt my laurels. The next morning the answers to correspondents never failed to inform them that, "The lines of L. S. were inadmissible;" or, "The Epigram signed Laura wont do for our Paper;" or "we must desire our fair correspondent Clarissa to learn to spell, before she pretends to write heroic verse." I wonder really at their impertinence;—that a young lady of fashion can't amuse herself in rhyming a little about her friends, but they must pretend to judge of the matter!
Oh, my dear Miss Archer! do you know that some cruel wretch here—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, yes, my dear, I know it all; you are the fifteenth lady who has been here this morning, to inform me of it. Upon my word a newspaper pasquinade is a mighty good thing—it makes one's friends remember one.

sp.speaker: JUV.
sp.p: Deuce take 'em! I thought to have been the first,—now I don't know how it touch'd her.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Why do you muse, my dear?

sp.speaker: JUV.
sp.p: Oh, muse—why I am musing upon the wickedness of people—to dare—to be able—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, never think about it. I tell you such things are rather a distinction—to be abused in a newspaper is to be rank'd with half the amiable and great characters in existence. Hah! here's another visitant, with another newspaper! Why my friends are so numerous, they'll be oblig'd to put forth another impression before noon. Good morning, Sir Marvel Mushroom!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, your most devoted! Have you heard of this scurrilous abuse?—Oh, yes, you have heard, I see;—Miss Juvenile is here.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: You might have met half your acquaintance here twenty minutes ago, they are kindly gone to disperse the papers.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Marvel, can you guess at the writer?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, that's not a fair question. What do you think of the lines?

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Pointed to the last degree! witty and severe!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: A'n't they?—this couplet

div2.stage: [They each read alternately, Miss ARCHER standing between them.]

sp.speaker: MARVEL.
sp.l: "Some forms won't yield to leathern traces."

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.l: "The blushes form'd with so much art,"

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: "The affected—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Nay, pray, good people! have a little compassion!

div2.stage: [She claps a hand before each mouth; they struggle to speak, with their eyes fixed on the papers; as she removes her hands, they each speak.]

sp.speaker: MARVEL.
sp.p: —"Clear starcher!"

sp.speaker: Miss JUVENILE.
sp.p: —"Miss Archer!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: What d'ye think of it, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: What is your motive for reading it to me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Motive—motive—why 'tis fit every body should know what's said of them. That great philosopher, Heliogabalus, said the abuses of his enemies were more serviceable to him than the praises of his friends.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I am quite of that opinion, and wish therefore, to know whom I have to thank for this service.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Do you? would you really wish to know him?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, really.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Shall I bring him to you?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Then you know him?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Perfectly well. I will not give his name, but if you have any curiosity, he shall receive your thanks in person this evening.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I should like it above all things. I have spent a life in hearing flatteries and falsehoods—let me for once see a man who has the courage to speak what he thinks. Pardon me for leaving you—I shall expect you and my panegyrist at seven.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: You see she can't stand it—she is finely nettled.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes, she feels it.—I am not surprised at it.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: I wonder what blockhead wrote it! for, between ourselves, I never read more wretched stuff.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Wretched stuff!

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Oh, vile! tho' I made her believe I thought it all wit and poignancy.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why really, Miss Juvenile, I am surprised that people will give opinions so rashly. Miss, the person who wrote this little morceau is remarkable for his skill in belles lettres.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Belles lettres!—skill in bell metal might do for such lines as these—they might be hammer'd out of any thing.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Very well, ma'am! very well! I must beg leave to say, that it is not so agreeable to hear the talents of one's friends slighted.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p:
Indeed! you are mighty liberal;—in general 'tis the most agreeable treat a friend can
have. I wish you wou'd let me know who this friend is, for whose reputation you are in such pain.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: What d'ye think of Mr. Carlton?

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: What do I think? ha, ha, ha!—My dear Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Nay, if you wont believe me, come this evening and see him here.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Well, really now, it is surprising!—I did not think he had possess'd so much ill-nature.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Ill-nature! Let me tell you, Miss Juvenile, private ill-nature may be a public good. To make people's time pass happily is very benevolent, and if it was not for a little pleasant thing of this sort, now and then in a morning, people's chocolate would be as dull and infipid as the Ve—Venetian black broth.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Spartan, I fancy you mean.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Spart—gad! that's very true; what a ridiculous mistake!—ha, ha, ha! Thank ye, Miss—thank ye. Yes, I remember now, the Venetians were those who joined the Macedonians in the war against Philip;—how could I make such a mistake!—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: One may as well be quiet—in trying to help the poor man out, he gets but the deeper in. (aside). Pray, Sir Marvel, order my chair.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, yes. Venetian!—how could I make such a mistake?

div2.head: SCENE, BELLAIR's Lodgings.
div2.stage: Carlton and Bellair arise from a table with glasses, &c.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
And so you really mean to persuade the
innocent thing, that running away with Harry Bellair is the most honourable step she can take?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At least the happiest; for does she not love me? What is her fate if she stays? She will be huddled, in less than three days, into a marriage, with a passion in her heart, adding bitterness to disgust and mortification.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Where would you place her to be in safety?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have a friend in town, the gravity of whose character will be a shield to her's. I have neglected him since I came from Leyden, but I'll go and make it up with him this very day. Let that pass—now to my question; will you assist in the enlevement?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: If I am not summon'd to the adorable Archer. If my scheme there takes place—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That's really too absurd! If she believes you to be the author of that vile abuse, and invites you, it must be to poison you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I don't care with what view it is, if I am but invited;—I shall be sure, at least, not to rank with the brilliant captains, the Sir Tommys, and Sir Neddys, who are receiv'd, court'sey'd to, and forgot.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, you'll certainly be remember'd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I am convinced that a woman who has been admired all over Europe, and returns with an untouch'd heart, is not to be won by flattery, or by stooping to her power. 'Tis pride secures her, and her pride must be taken down, before Love can find a vulnerable place for his darts.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That will do for a figure—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Aye, and for a reason too;—I shall govern myself by it, however.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: The person you sent for, Sir, is in the parlour.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll attend him—excuse me half a moment.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel Mushroom enquires for you, Sir, he has been at your lodgings, and was directed hither.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Admit him! admit him! [he enters] My dear Sir Marvel, what news from the lady?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I found her as inflammable as one of Montgolfier's balloons. The whole town had been with her—the whole town is mad about my satire!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Then 'tis in vain for me to hope for the credit of being it's author—it is not in mortal wight to lend so much reputation, for half an hour.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, but you are mistaken—I disclaim'd it—disclaim'd all the glory—and she desires this evening to see the incomparable author.—So you will, Pyramus like, drive, for one day, the chariot of the Sun.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Shall I?—will she see me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: She pants for an interview: the beauteous Helen was not more desirous of receiving Leander, when he swam every night-across the Mediterranean. I have promised to carry you this evening. But be sure you don't give me as the poet, 'till I give the word.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nothing can be farther from my design—You shall gather your laurels when you please. I prize this mode of introduction so highly, that I know not how to return the favour.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, Lord, nothing can be so easy. I hear you have a pretty poetical quill, and that you sometimes write Latin verses;—publish a volume, and call it mine.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I'll consider it.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You may throw in a touch of Greek, too. I should learn Greek, for the pleasure of reading Ovid, but their d—d crooked characters are so alike, that one may as well attempt to learn Spanish, of Dutch mackerel.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear friend, I am too impatient to give the time I ought to your erudition;—I had rather hold a convention with my taylor and valet than with Ovid and Horace; and had rather this night be as well drest as Count Grammont, than as well read as Doctor Johnson.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Hah, my dear Mr. Bellair! Will you excuse me; I can't stay—I came to call on Mr. Carlton. I have done his business for him—He's going to visit the lady, and he swears he'll be as well drest as Doctor Johnson.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you know your business. You are to go to Mr. Feelove's, and tell him—But stay, can you weep on occasion?

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, I don't doubt but I can squeeze a tear, upon a pinch.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, squeeze as many as you can; and tell him that your wife is in extremity at Hampstead, and desires his immediate assistance.

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: My wife!—then I'd better not cry, Sir; it won't seem so natural.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Well, manage that as you will.—Here is something for your ingenuity—Be sure, at all events you see the Doctor into his chariot, and give him a direction to some house in Hampstead.

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: Never fear me—I humbly thank ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: So! having made a clear road for the Doctor, I can fearlesly pursue my own. My sweet Arabella! in ten minutes I'll be at thy feet.

div2.stage: [EVERGREEN asleep on a sopha, ARABELLA sitting at work, on a chair. After looking on him, she rises.]

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, how different it seems when Mr. Bellair is on that sopha! I could sit and look at him for ever. If he was asleep, I'd take such care that nothing should disturb him;—but I don't look at him with any pleasure—I don't care whether he wakes or no.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [beginning to wake.] Never fear, Doctor, she'll be— [yawning]—she'll be a very good girl.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: To be sure, I must try to be good; but I shall never be happy, though!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
Mind what I say, my pretty Bell—The
young fellows—the young fellows are all rogues, villains, and—heydey! where's the Doctor?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: He's gone to Hampstead.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hampstead! Why, how long have I been asleep? Bless me! [looking at his watch.] 'Tis six o'clock.—I must go—A'n't you sorry, my pretty Bell?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Not sorry!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why must I be sorry?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Because I am going to leave you. When you are my wife you must be sorry always in my absence, and glad in my presence.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why must I be glad?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why!—why because I am with you, to talk to you, and to warn you against the ensnaring devices of young men, who, like spiders, spread their cobwebs every where, to catch such silly flies as you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear me, how can you think so? Spiders are frightful creatures, but young men are not frightful. When my uncle took me out in his chariot, they looked at me so kindly! If I had been their sister, they could not have seemed to like me better.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, they would not then have liked you so well. But you are very ignorant, Bell; very ignorant, indeed! However, you have time enough to improve.—When you are Lady Penmanmaure, you'll be quite a different thing. Good by'e, pretty Bell! you shall see me again to-night.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
I don't care whether I ever see you again or not. It's very odd now—every time I see him, I like him worse and worse; and every time I see Mr. Bellair
I like him better and better. [Enter SERVANT] Thomas, if Mr. Bellair should come, don't say my uncle is out, then perhaps he'll go away, and won't come up.

sp.speaker: THOMAS.
sp.p: He is here now, Miss. He seem'd very sorry that my master was absent; but said he'd wait to have some of your sal volatile, when his Lordship was gone—and he sent me now to ask if you'd admit him.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes!—How glad I am my Lord is gone. Dear me, now, I am all in a flutter! What can make me tremble so?

div2.stage: Enter BELLAIR, leaning on a Servant.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Gently! gently! Support me to the sopha.—There! now you may go. [Exit SERVANT.] Your drops, sweet young lady!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Here they are, Sir;—I hope they'll do you good.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Do you hope so! [holding both her hands.]—Do you wish me to recover?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: There is nothing in the world I wish for so much.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Who knows but it may be in your power?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! you can't recover. My uncle says—and you know he is a great Doctor—that you must dye.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [still holding her hands.] And can you bear to see me dye?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No, I shan't see you die; and I hope I never shall hear of it. But I shall know it; for I shall then see you no more.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I am sorry you are in such pain—you see how bad you are; you'll hardly be able to come any more—But I have something to comfort me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What!—what!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I have your picture—I drew it myself—Nobody would know it to be you but me;—but I can make out all your face.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, God of Love! thou canst have no happiness in store for me after this!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, don't fear, Sir!—you will be very happy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes!—yes, most adorable! I shall indeed be happy, for thou hast pronounced it. See at your feet the most faithful and passionate of lovers. You have been deceived in me; I am not dying—except I dye now, through excess of bliss.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Gracious!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It will take too long to explain now, how first I saw, how first I loved you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What do you love me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: More than my life! and I come to save you from misery. You are on the brink of marriage with a man you must hate.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: How can you save me from that?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By marrying you myself.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What may you marry me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, sweet innocence!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I thought I could marry nobody but that old Lord?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, you shall never marry him, unless you choose it.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Choose it!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is but one way to prevent it;—you must leave your uncle's house, put yourself under my protection, and then become the mistress of my fate.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: And when must I do this?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To-night.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Goodness! and is it really in my power not to marry him, and to marry you? and will it be my duty to love you, and to sit by you, and to watch your slumbers?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, my angel! whilst it continues to be your choice, never think about the duty. Will you be ready to go with me to-night?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Go with you! Yes, indeed—But where?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am now going to prevail on a friend of mine to honour his house, by making it your asylum 'till you remove to your own. I will be in the street at ten; a dark lanthorn shall be my signal—The moment you perceive it, leave the roof under which your ruin has been plann'd.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I will, indeed.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Let nothing stop you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No—not if my uncle was to beg ever so much.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: One kiss from each dear hand—'tis all I will ask 'till you are my own. Adieu! Remember ten.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
Can it be all true? Mr. Bellair not dying, and loves me, and I to be his wife! It is—it is! these
dear marks on my hands are real— [kissing them.] Oh, happy, happy Arabella!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Sir, a shentleman is without, and has creat occasions to speak to you.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Did I not say—

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Cot a mercy! I tolt him you sait so; and he sait you would see him—He is your cotson from Leyton.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Godson! What, Harry Bellair? Hah! [looking through the wing.] it is him, sure enough.—Harry! come in, Harry! [Enter BELLAIR.] Why, you rogue you, how long have you been return'd from Leyden? and how can you have the impudence to be grown thus tall and big? Hark ye! take care you forget that I was a greybeard at your christening, you young dog you!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At least I shall not be so malicious as to remember it on your wedding-day, which I am told is very near.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hah! have you heard that? The devil's in this town for gossiping. Formerly a man could do a snug thing in London, and the business as little known as though it were transacted on Penmanmaure—But now one's most private concerns are as public as the secrets of a prime minister.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why should so splendid an event as your marriage—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: None of your jeers! What, I suppose, you expect to be introduced to my bride—I shan't do it. I shan't do it, godson—There's your answer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then I shall be kinder than you; for I'll introduce you to mine—Nay, before she is my bride; I'll intrust her to your care in all her virgin charms.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No great compliment in that, perhaps. But are you going to be married then?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I hope so; but, to confess—it is a kind of a run-away business. I am this very night to carry off the lady, and I come now to solicit your permission to bring her here.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: With all my heart—with all my heart, Harry. But who is she?—what is she?—whence is she?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She is a blooming girl, on the point of being decoy'd into marriage with a man old enough to be her grandfather, and dotard enough to believe that the enchanted circle of a wedding ring will conjure in her a blindness to his defects, and a passion for his wrinkles.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hay! [dryly] Why there are some prudent girls, Mr. Bellair, who have no objection to a husband a little on the down-hill of life.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, I beg your pardon! I am sure I did not mean to infinuate that—that—What is he going to marry a prudent girl?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well but—gad, 'tis laughable too. Ha, ha! How old is the little tit?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Of that delightful age which women term childish, and which girls think womanish;—she is the niece of an eminent physician; and the man, to whom he is going to marry her, is a superannuated peer.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
[aside.] Hell and devils! But stay—there
are more old fools than I.—The name, Sir;—the Doctor's name?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Feelove;—and his lovely niece is Arabella Melville.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I have a red hot iron in my liver.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why do you whistle, Sir?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing. 'Tis a droll story you tell me—that's all. And pray how did you get acquainted with the young woman?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I saw her with her uncle in Hyde Park—was struck with the air of innocence, and enquiry that distinguished her—followed the carriage—learnt that she was just brought from Cornwall, to be married to a gouty Lord—introduced myself as a patient—robb'd the niece of her heart, and let the uncle rob me of my guineas.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well done, uncle Toby!—wise uncle Toby! Gad, there's something very odd in all this! And you are going to carry her off to-night?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: And you wish to bring her here?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ardently.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, I shall take it d—d ill, if you carry her any where else.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is not another house in London I would trust her in.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Bring her! bring her away! I'll take as much care of the little rogue, as though it was my own affair.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How shall I thank—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, you'll know what thanks to pay me in a day or two.—Go, my dear Harry!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your cagerness charms me.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Go—go—go! [pushing him out.]—Ha, ha, ha!—Oh! oh! oh! I could cry heartily on one side, but the other won't let me for laughing. Now, which shall I do? Oh, a sly gypsey! Oh, a d—d old fool of a Doctor! That he should bring her a gallant!—that she should consent to run off with him!—and that he should humbly solicit to put her under my wing!!!—Well, it shall all work together for good. Instead of the Lord, may I be Goat of Penmanmoure, if this shan't be a means of squeezing me another five thousand out of Feelove. I have it working here—'tis working here. David! David!

div2.stage: [Miss ARCHER discovered with a Harp, on which she strikes a few notes. A rapping is heard—she rises with precipitation.]

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: MY sweet harp, I must abandon thee! That rap announces my satyrist. Ha, ha! Now, I really wonder, though I wish to see him, how he can look me in the face:—he must be most ridiculously confused—trying at fifty awkward apologies. Oh, it is Miss Juvenile—impatient, I suppose, to see the bard.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Bless me, is he gone! I run away the moment we rose from table. I would not have miss'd him for the world.—Who would have expected him to be gone so soon? Not eight yet.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Who, indeed? But people's fears, when they dread great misfortunes, are generally unruly. Why, my dear Ma'am, you'll be happy yet—The charming man who lash'd me has not been here.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Oh, that's lucky! I do want much to see what sort of a man he is.—She shan't know that I could tell her.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, I can draw his picture, I am sure, exactly. A great fat man, in a black coat, with twinkling eyes, and a prodigious length of profile—he makes amazing low bows—sits down, with his hat resting on his knees; and after wiping his face, stuffs his red and white pocket handkerchief in the crown of it.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel Mushroom, and another Gentleman.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! my dear Sir Marvel, that was in the very first style. Do you know—Ladies, your most obedient! [passing them with a sliding bow]—Do you know the very thing happened to me at Padua! Miss Archer, I am happy to wait on you.—We were all in the Marchezza's box that night, when her husband came from Paris—she is extremely handsome; he toute au contrarie! but, notwithstanding—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Bless me, can't you tell your story afterwards? Let me introduce you to Miss Archer. This, Madam, is the gentleman who had honour to day to entertain the town with—with that little—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, a mere trifle! not worth mentioning, Sir Marvel. Miss Archer, I hear you have been a traveller; and that, when in Italy, they persuaded you to visit some of the Levant Islands. I wonder, when so far, your taste did not carry you to Greece! You can conceive nothing so charming as the Grecian women!—nothing so interesting as their style of living!—you would have found all Arcadia realiz'd.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Greece and Arcadia!—are these his apologies!—his aukward embarrassments!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I endeavoured to persuade a fair Greek, that the fate of my countrywomen was happier than their's.—"Oh, it is impossible," said she; "their liberty makes them capricious, and their power over the men assuming; they grow old in planning new conquests, and, alive only to the pleasure of admiration, seldom taste the exquisite bliss of true passion." I felt the force of her observation, and could not help confessing that it was possible for a handsome English woman to border on the ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: [Aside] So! that's tolerably home.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aside] I am petrified! he talks with as much self-possession as he would to a maiden aunt—no bearing this!

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: So you will not know me, Mr. Carlton?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Miss Juvenile!—'tis no wonder I did not immediately recollect you in that dress, when I left you in a white frock. I saw your brother well at Vienna. You play, Miss Archer. I am charm'd that you prefer the harp—'tis so graceful for the lady—so advantageous for the voice.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: [In a pet] Why 'tis downright jingle!—a wooden cimbal is a better thing! I thought to have heard nothing but what concern'd my ver—I mean your verses; and here you have whisk'd us to Padua, then to Greece, then we had a swing to Vienna in Turkey, and now we must have a Canterbury tale about the merits of the Welch harp. Why, I tell you, Miss Archer, this is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p:
Yes, Miss Archer, this is the gentleman,
who travell'd all over Europe, to qualify himself to write an epigram on you;—I think he might have managed the matter without going so far for his wit.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: If he got his wit far off, you must allow it touches home.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Yes;—I allow it is homely wit.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Heavens! how could this man! [aside] Miss Juvenile means to be severe upon you, Sir, but don't be disheartened. When you have done with me, you'll find a number of innocent, unprotected characters, who, at no other expence than a private heart-ache, may be securely offered up victims to your muse.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I disclaim all connection with the muses—nothing inspires me but the subject.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: You were happy in the choice of a subject to day; was he not, my dear? Have you the paper about you, Sir Marvel?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, to be sure—here it is.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pardon me! I am not yet so harden'd a writer, as to stand the reading of my own works.
sp.stage: [Snatches the paper with anger, and puts it in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aside] Now, would I give the world to know, if that is in compassion to his own feelings, or to mine.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir! not hear your own works! Why, it is what every body does, and read 'em too.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, to be sure—the ladies carry their's about in their netting cases, and the men in their toothpick cases.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed;—we learn those kind of
works now, like every other, at boarding school. I, myself, have written five odes, seven epigrams, and an elegy on an old turkey cock. Come, read, Mr. Carlton—you'll give your satire new points.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: These wretches will force me to spoil my plan, by their cruelty to the lovely sufferer.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: May I be permitted to ask, how I came to have the honour of your poetical notice?—Did I ever offend you?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Never, Madam! with respect to me, you have been perfectly harmless.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Would I had not! for the first time in my life I wish to do mischief.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I never had the honour of your acquaintance; and have seen you but seldom in public; but last spring I particularly remember, at the Pantheon.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: That's well! particularly remember!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It was impossible to forget it;—you had in your party so lovely a girl! Bright blue eyes, flaxen tresses, elegant shape, modest—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
