sp.p: [Impatiently] What has all this to do with your satire on me, Sir? Why have you taken pains to represent me to the world in so odious a light?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, one does many things without reflection. I happened to be in the humour to write—Your name occurred—The thing was done—My friends liked it—They would have it appear. I'll give you leave to abuse me with fifty times the wit.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Fifty times as much wit! gad! I don't know where she'd find it.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Then you do not think me, Sir, so very—I understand, you do not think me so extremely odious and frightful!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, that submissive look! such another will bring me at her feet, and then I am undone.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Do you hear, Mr. Carlton? is the lady so very odious, and frightful?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Frightful! Oh, no, Madam. The lady is very well—I wish I had abated a point or two in my epigram. She is tolerably fair, not a very bad shape, and, upon the whole, a—a most bewitching creature.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir, do you think I can stand here to be analyzed in this manner? Pardon me, if I say you scarcely keep within the line of good manners. I did not expect—not that I care.—I would not have you think that—that—I can bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, those tears! that I could catch them, and bury them in my heart!

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—well, she's finely mortified. My dear Mr. Carlton, I have the most extreme favour to beg of you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: You have interest with the news-papers—I have some very elegant, spirited things, and shall be prodigously obliged, if you'll get 'em in for me.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Ma'am, I really—

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Nay, I will not be denied.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: No, no,—don't deny the lady.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: A word! [Takes him aside.] I have one thing that would cut Sir Marvel to shivers.—If you will but get that one thing published.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes, get that one thing published, by all means.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: To oblige you, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Oh, charming!—I'll bring it to you myself to-morrow. Now I'll go to Miss Archer, and tell her you are going home to compose another satire on her.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Go, thou thing! and prosecute my heart's dearest interests, whilst you believe yourself only gratifying your girlish spite!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: In the midst of all Miss Archer's anger, she does not pretend to despise the verses.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Despise them! I design to make her acknowledge that they are the happiest verses that ever were written;—you have really very extraordinary talents.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Talents!—aye, but every body thinks he has talents now-a-days! as Homer says in the Rape of the Lock,
sp.l: To wit each blockhead makes pretence;
Give me a little common sense.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Amen, Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Mighty pretty! mighty pretty! I can never come in to my house, but I am jostled by two or three young fellows going out of it. Hark ye, Sir! In future when any body, male or female, asks for Miss Archer, say she's not at home. If I can't get her out of the house, she shall see nobody in it—that will surely do in the long run. She may live without a husband, but to live without gossiping, without flatterers, without all the he and she family of nonsense, that I take to be impossible. D'ye mind me?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes sure I to, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well then, mind me again. Mr. Bellair will bring a lady here presently—tell him I am out—sent for by the Welch Committee, about the new linen manufactory;—but say I left strict orders with the housekeeper to take care of the lady.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes, I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, aye—they are together by this time, driving to me, their only friend and guardian! ha, ha, ha! I saw the dog watching the door, and I saw him hold up a lantern—that was the signal, I suppose, ha, ha, ha!—Pretty creatures! Oh, I have them fast—they have made a noose for their own necks. Of an unfortunate man, I am surely the most fortunate that ever.

sp.speaker: BELLAIR,
sp.p: At the committee, do you say?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My dearest angel 'tis unfortunate; but you are now in the house of Mr. Evergreen, and his protection will be of the most conclusive sort, with respect to your reputation; and your reputation is now mine. Why do you sigh?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I don't know—but I am afraid they'll take me from you again.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never; I swear by every thing sacred, that I'll hold you to me as I would my life. I'll go directly down to the house to bring home my friend; I cannot bear that you should be in this unguarded slate, and for many reasons I ought not to remain with you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Not remain with me! why are we not to be married?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
Doubtless! and then we shall be inseperable;
but custom says we must not be so 'till we are married.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why, how will custom know any thing about us?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, there are a thousand eyes upon us. Of what a nature is innocence! it invites its ruin; and the more pure it is, the nearer to destruction. [Aside.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Well, if you must leave me, make haste to return. How shall I amuse myself in your absence? Oh, here are some paintings. I love paintings dearly—I can look at them and make out whole conversations, between unhappy girls, and their cross uncles, and fathers.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But look now, my angel, for another subject—search for the portrait of a lover; fancy him telling the beauty he adores, that his whole life is devoted to her felicity;—fancy that I am that lover, and yourself the charming girl. [kissing her hand] Heaven guard thee!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: The happy girl, he should have said. Oh, I shall find no portrait here so charming as he is.

div2.stage: [As she is looking at the paintings, EVERGREEN enters, and stands in her way;—she turns, and seeing him, shrieks.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How now, young woman! why so frightened?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! oh dear!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How came you here, child—hey?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: How—Oh goodness! how came you here?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, I am intimate here—I make as free as though I were at home.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Indeed!—Oh, he'll go and tell my uncle where to find me. What shall I do? [Aside.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, Bell! Bell! have I not always told you to beware of young men? have I not told you that they are all made up of deceit and lies?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, you have told me so, but I don't believe you. And you told me that I was made on purpose to be your wife, and that I don't believe neither.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Indeed! why, who then are you made for?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Somebody.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, but not for the body you think of, my pretty Bell. Oh, you little goose you! why this was a scheme plan'd between Bellair and me. This is my house; and he has brought you here, to deliver you solely into my power.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, what a story! how can you say such false things? he'd die before he'd put me in your power.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Would he so? why I have been in his secret the whole time. I know of his sham sickness to impose on your wise uncle, and of his persuading you that he had a godfather, under whose care he would place you. I know of the signal of the dark lantern, and every particular about ye—Now what do you think of young men?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Think! oh merciful! I could not have believ'd that in all the world there had been such—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, now, are they not deceitful monsters? and Bellair in particular, is he not—tell me? [snatching her hand] is he not the worst of men?—a most cruel villain?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What for putting me in your power?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, no, no,—I mean for—'Gad she had me!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, it is very cruel indeed. I think now I could hate him. Oh, I wish he would come, that I might tell him how I hate him!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, but he won't come—or, if he does, it will be to no purpose; he shall never see you more, my pretty Bell, 'till you are my wife.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: If I was sure it would make him miserable, I could almost determine to be your wife—and yet I would rather die.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, you ungrateful baggage! so much love, so much tenderness as I have thrown away upon you!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Its very strange! I would help it if I could, but indeed I cannot. He who has been so cruel, I cannot hate; and you, who have been so kind, I cannot love.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I am much obliged t'ye, Ma'am, for your confidence.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why should I deceive you?—you think Mr. Bellair very wicked in deceiving me, and pretending to love me, when he did not. I will not pretend to love you; if I did, you ought to think me a very wicked girl.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: So, so, so. Well, Ma'am, with regard to the matter of love, we'll settle that hereafter;—perhaps we are more even there than you think for—but, at present, I have other business in hand. Here, Mrs. Jones, [Enter Housekeeper] take care of this young lady;—tempt her to eat if you can, and if you cannot, put her to bed supperless.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Must I go to bed without seeing Mr. Bellair, to reproach him.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I'll reproach, when the time comes, never fear; but he shan't enter these doors to night. Go, Mrs. Jones—go! [Exeunt.] Now will I to my Doctor; by this time he is apprized of his loss; and I'll see him poison'd before I'll tell him where she is. Oh, Doctor! Doctor!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Go down, Mrs. Jones, I'll comfort the young lady. My sweet girl, who are ye? what is the occasion of this extreme distress.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, you seem good-natured, and I'll tell ye. Mr. Bellair has betrayed me, and Lord Penmanmawr is determined to marry me.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Who are these people?—I never heard their names.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear!—why this must be a very large house then, for Lord Penmanmawr lives in it; and Mr. Bellair I run away with, to marry—but I don't know where he lives.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Heavens! run away with a man to marry him, and not know where he lives! why, my dear, he may be a deceiver.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, so he is, a very great deceiver; for he brought me here to Lord Panmanmawr, and call'd him Mr. Evergreen;—and now he won't marry me himself, and wants to force me to marry the old lord. [Weeping.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
Lord Penmanmawr, and call'd him Evergreen! I don't know what to understand. But come, my love, you shall go with me to my dressing
room, and we'll talk it over;—if you want an adviser, you shall find a sincere one in me. Her heart has an attachment, and it seems an unfortunate one—I know too well, now, how to pity her.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE,
sp.p: Gone! gone! gone off! I can't believe it—'tis impossible. She knows nobody—speaks to nobody. In all this vast town there cannot be a house open to her. And here have I been sent on a fool's errand to Hampstead, where every body is in health—not a soul sick from the top of the Heath, to Mother Red Caps. But she can't be gone off!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, here's a fine pill for ye, Doctor!—here's a bitter potion! Whilst you have been running after an old woman's sciatica at Hampstead, your niece has been running away with a young man.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are we to do? Why do we stand here? Why don't we go in search of her?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Search of her!—where? where are we to go? And if we find her, what then? who d'ye think is to take your tarnish'd plate off your hands? We, indeed! 'tis all your affair, now Doctor; I wash my hands on't entirely.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What do you mean? Why, is she not contracted to you?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Contracted to me—yes, in a state of unblemished reputation.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Her reputation is yet unblemished, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, but it won't be so to-morrow morning—the first sun beams will see the flies upon it, and by noon it will be stale—stale, Doctor!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir! this is going too far;—you are too violent in your conjectures;—after all it may be but a girl's frolic—stray'd to some toyshop, or confectioner's, perhaps.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Toyshop! or confectioner's! [contemptuously] What, then, you have not found out, all this time, that she is really run off with a young fellow, and who her gallant is! whu! have I that news to tell you? come, Doctor, prepare for a surprize—loosen your neckcloth, take off your wig, slacken all your ligatures, and sit down for a fit.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: [Angrily] Slacken your wit, Sir! you are too jocose on the subject of a young lady's reputation.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Young lady's repution! there are more reputations than her's at stake, I promise ye;—the reputation of a wise man—a Doctor's reputation, will become the tennis ball of all the wits in town in a few hours. Oh, Doctor, Doctor! where did you take up your diploma for discretion?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir! there is no bearing—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
Yes, but there is—Hark ye! I shall make ye, in one minute, as mute as the bust of old Galen in your study. This great, impudent, roaring, debauch'd fellow, who has carried off your niece without let or hindrance, is the poor puling patient, who was brought to your house every day for the benefit of the park air; and whom you have pronounced to be beyond
the skill of all the physicians in Europe, to keep out of a winding sheet.—Now, Doctor, you find there are more reputations than your niece's at stake.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: A malicious invention of your own—sheer malice!—That poor young gentleman is in a state, and I will prove it, to make it impossible for him to recover. The morbid matter (speaking very eagerly) hourly increases; the viscera do not perform their functions—secretion is destroyed—the thorax inflamed, the—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I tell you he is run away with your niece.

sp.speaker: (FEELOVE
sp.stage: continues to speak without regarding the other's interruptions.)
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, that such an attack on my character
(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—a man of my experience, Mr. Evergreen
—(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—I who am acknowledged by every apothecary within the bills of mortality
—(I tell you is run away with your niece)
—[Going off, the other following]—I who am call'd to every capital consultation
—(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—I whose practice has been so singularly successful—

sp.speaker: BELLAIR.
sp.p: My dear Carlton, congratulate me!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Congratulate me!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have carried off my prize.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have been with Miss Archer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have safely lodged her in the house of a friend.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have seen the most tender melancholy in her air.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have seen love light up all her features; and have pressed my Arabella to my heart.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have press'd Miss Archer to mine too, in idea; and my hopes tell me, that it will not be only in idea. I am now convinced of her sensibility, and adore her. But where is your Arabella?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At the friends I mentioned. Not being able to find him at Westminster, I called at his house in my return, and have been assured that the dear girl herself, Mr. Evergreen, and all the family are retired to rest.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Evergreen! he's Miss Archer's guardian—she lives in his house.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then our Mistresses are under the same roof—that's most fortunate!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It is indeed; for two girls talking to each other of the men they love, will do more for us in a day, than we could for ourselves in a week.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove! Oh, all the demons of mischance!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Can he have made the discovery so soon?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
[Speaking as he enters.] A villain! to attempt thus to undermine my reputation. Gentlemen,—I have been insulted so grossly, that I can hardly compose myself, to tell you the cause of my unseasonable
visit—but—if—in one word, how is my poor patient—how is Mr. Bellair?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir! Mr. Bellair—Sir!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: He does not know ye—fear nothing.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: My patient, Sir—good gentlemen speak! how is my patient?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your patient, Sir, is as well as a patient can be, who is out of the reach of his d—d Doctor. No further occasion for asses milk, stimulatives, balsamics, or coolers.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Alas, poor Doctor!—no more fees—he has given you the go-by fairly. Is it not a shame that a man of your prowess in the fields of Galen, should not be able to conquer such a pitiful hectic as drove him him out of the world? why, a physician ought to have the diseases at his call, and whistle them on and off, as a huntsman does his hounds.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Aye, 'twas a crying sin, to let such a spirited fine young fellow be kick'd out of life by a rascally little feveret! An old woman would have cured him; but such an obstinate confidence in the skill of the renown'd Doctor Feelove! He died full of resentment, and his last words were—"Toss the Doctor in a blanket."

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I can forgive that—I can forgive that—but I can't forgive your illiberality, Sir. An old woman cure him! It was not in the power of all the physicians between London and the Alps to cure him;—not an herb, gum, wood, or fungus in the whole medicopeia, that could have given him breath two days longer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis false, Sir—Bring the blanket!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I could not bear this treatment, Sir, but that the extreme satisfaction I have in Mr. Bellair's death.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Satisfaction!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. My reputation, my character, demanded that he should die.—I would not have had him alive to-morrow morning for a thousand pound fee.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This is amazing!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Why, Sir, there is a vile story in circulation, which, if true, would sink me beneath the lowest med'cine grinder—beneath a mixer of eggs and turpentine—beneath the cork in a julep bottle; nothing less than that Bellair is in perfect health, and so alive to youth and beauty, as to have run away with my niece—they say that!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What is there this world will not say! By all the honour of physic, he has a dose in his pocket to have secured his reputation, had he found thee alive!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [Apart] We'll search him, and make him swallow it. But have you then lost the young lady?—is she gone?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Gone, Sir—absolutely gone; but as my poor patient is gone too, I am in some measure reconciled to that event. But, bless me, Sir, you are vastly like him—a man more liable to be imposed on, might take ye both for the same person;—the same voice, and the same features, only fresher and plumper.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Oh, oh—What you have found me out, Doctor? Why, I am his brother—your poor patient's younger brother,—and I should break my heart for his death, only the dog has left me a clear estate of two
thousand a year, to buy weepers. In short, Doctor, I greatly fear'd your skill would preserve him, and if it had!—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Preserve him! you might as well have expected my skill in physic to have preserv'd the French bank from breaking.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, notwithstanding my affected petulance at your entrance, I am highly gratified that Bellair is where he is—and I'll recommend you to all my friends and acquaintance. But I wonder the loss of your niece sits so lightly, my little Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I have a great heart—a prodigious great heart! its feelings are for the faculty. A girl may run away from an uncle without reproach to him; but when a patient runs away from the sentence of his physician, the reputation of the doctor must soon run after him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Happily our patient knew his duty better;—and so, as we are now three very happy fellows, let us e'en adjourn to the Star and Garter, and live the evening like bon vivants.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: With all my heart;—and egad, gentlemen, I am so offended with the insolence of a certain person, whom I will not name, that if you'll discover my niece, I'll give her to ye, with a fortune of twenty thousand pounds. The odd ten I'll stick to.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Hah! say ye so? If I discover her, shall she be my reward?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That she shall.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: May I rely on your promise.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
With as much confidence, as on the
symptoma of a fever. I would give her to a rincer of gallipots, rather than the person I had engaged her to;—to a pill vender—to a mountebank.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bravo, Doctor! keep to that, and we'll discover her enchanted castle, never fear!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: That we will. Allons! let us sacrifice to Bacchus to-night, and to-morrow to Esculapius, and Fortune!

div2.head: SCENE, FEELOVE's.
div2.stage: Enter FEELOVE, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: NOTHING of my niece this morning! Oh, may that rascal, who cheated me yesterday to Hampstead, never get rid of his wife till he is seventy-six; and then, for his farther punishment, may he grow rich, and fall in love!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: May I be so bold, Sir—is that a curse?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: A curse! why, can there be greater, than for a man to fall into riches, when he has neither time nor faculties to enjoy them; and to fall in love, whilst he is falling into his grave? If they are blessings, may they be the lot of knaves, and cowards, and quacks! Bring me the slate, that I may see where I am to go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Go! why go to find your niece, to be sure. Have you heard nothing from her yet?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Come, how much will you add now to the fifteen thousand, if I should discover, and bring her t'ye?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What! consider what you say!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I do consider what I say!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How! if I discover your niece, drag her from her seducer, and in that state of her reputation take her off your hands, and make her Mistress Evergreen—what will you not throw in five thousand for that?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, Mister Evergreen—not five guineas—not five shillings—not a single half-crown. Oh, how I could mortify him now, by telling him Bellair is dead!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Here! here's an unreasonable man! So then, if I discover, and marry her, I am to have only fifteen thousand pounds!—Oh Lord! oh Lord!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Fifteen thousand pounds! why you shan't have her at all. Fifteen thousand pounds! If I thought my niece would ever look upon thee, or ever think of thee as a husband, I'd put fifteen thousand pounds in each pocket, drive to Gravesend, and leap into the sea, to disappoint thee.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, we'd have you up again, if you did—we'd empty your pockets, I warrant you. Riches are no more safe now in the bottom of the sea, than a rainbow is in the clouds. Neither earth, sea, or air, in this happy age, can keep their secrets from us; and I have no doubt but some bold adventurer in the next, will find out a way to live in fire; or dart from continent to continent, like Milton's angels, on a condens'd sun-beam.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That may be possible; but for you to marry my niece, with my consent, is impossible.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What, are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: In earnest—aye, as earnest as you was in your abuse of me last night. Smoke the Doctor, I suppose, was the word. You love a joke, old friend; so do I; and mine shall cost less than your's—so good morning t'ye! I shall prescribe another husband for my niece, depend on't.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Say you so, my old boy? Why then I must play a game I did not think of—I must secure the young woman 'till you can be brought to alter your prescription. I have made a pretty mess here! 'Gad, though I love a joke, I did not think I was buying mine at the dear rate of fifteen thousand pounds—Dangerous joking with doctors I find. Well, well, a wise man may fall into mistakes as well as a fool; but a wise man will find a way to remedy them.

div2.head: SCENE, EVERGREEN's.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I am charm'd to see you so well this morning. Has Lord Penmanmawr visited you?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, yes; and he left me to go to my uncle's; but I made him promise not to tell that I am here.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: You did not hint that you knew him to be Mr. Evergreen?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, no—I will do nothing but what you bid me. I should be easy now, could I but see Mr. Bellair, to vent my anger, and to tell him how I hate him.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
Have a care, my dear girl! you
wish to see him, I have no doubt; but should he appear, you'd forget your motives for that wish.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, never! was there ever so base—so—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Never, I acknowledge it; yet, should he invent any plausible excuse, your greedy ear would swallow it all. May I not judge her from myself? Should Mr. Carlton form excuses, where would my resentments be?

div2.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, speaking at the Wing.

sp.speaker: EVERGREEN.
sp.p: So! there's Satan at the ear of Eve [Aside]. Did I not desire, Miss Archer, that you would hold no correspondence with this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, my dear Guardian, and therefore I made a point of seeing her, and giving her a little sisterly advice. She knows by this time how to deceive your vigilance on common occasions, and on uncommon ones I have promised to assist her.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Assist her! (contemptuously) Well, Miss Melville, are you prepar'd to meet your uncle?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! is he coming!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How he gain'd knowledge of your being here, I know not, unless it is from your false Bellair; but he swears vengeance—a garret and water-gruel are the least of his threats.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, Miss Archer! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
What signifies appealing to her? Miss Archer, indeed! I have contrived what is to become of you; for I would not deliver my little Bell up to her uncle in his present fury for a dukedom, and to conceal you from him here will be impossible; I have therefore
a chaise ready at the door, to carry you a few miles out of town.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Out of town!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, Madam—or in town, or where I please—you won't presume to interfere, I hope.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I hope Miss Melville will refuse to go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Let her at her peril! she is my affianc'd wife; my wife betroth'd—I have perfect right over her. Go you, Madam, to your apartment, and leave her to my care.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My dear Girl, never go with him; who knows where he may carry you!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What can I do? I fear to go with him, and I am terrified to death at the thoughts of seeing my uncle.

div2.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, with a long white stuff Cloak, and large Hood.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Here, here's a Welch riding-cloak, that belonged to a tall, meagre aunt of mine; 'tis a little too long, I believe; but it will conceal you the better. Put it on, and pull the hood over, that your face mayn't be seen. Nay, don't be restive, Miss (throwing it loosely over her): put it on, whilst I replenish my purse.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Lady, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My sweet Girl, how can I assist you? What an arbitrary wretch! I am full of grief for you—What has not this Bellair to answer for?

div2.stage: [They weep over each other, retiring back.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
I must give up Hyde Park this morning—I'd be sworn Carlton will be here, and I am determined
to make one in their tête-à-tête. Hey, hey! why, Ladies!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: [turning] Oh, Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: And weeping too! Dionysius-like—no, Niobe-like, all tears.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: A thought strikes me—you can assist us. My guardian is going to hurry this young lady out of town, we know not where.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, I saw the chaise at the door—shall I go and break the axle, or shoot the horses?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: No, no—put on this cloak [taking it from the ground]—ride with him a few miles, then turn upon him, and terrify him to death. I suppose your vis-a-vis is waiting; I'll use it, to convey her out of his reach—instantly—instantly!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Stop! [when the cloak is half on] Hold! I will not be envelop'd in this new-fashion'd chemise—how could I be such a good-natur'd fool? Have you not repuls'd me, Madam—disdain'd me?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Sir Marvel! consider, 'tis for this young lady—she has not repuls'd you.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I'm at one word—off it goes, unless you'll promise to receive me on terms.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh heavens! I—I—I'll do better; I'll introduce you on terms to the pretty widow, Lady Beauville—she's just becoming the rage—'twill be infinite eclat—she had all the men in the pit about her t'other night at the opera.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: On with it! we are upon honour—you shall carry me there to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: To-night—any time. Come, Miss Melville!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: So, here am I going, Jupiter knows where, cased up like the Trojans in a wooden horse, or like—but here comes my ravisher.

div2.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, tying up his purse.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, what Madam has left you! Aye, she's a bad girl, Bell—a bad girl! never heed her! Come, don't cry, that's a good girl!—Devil take the string! Hide your face though as much as you will—that's right, pull the hood closer, for who knows but the Doctor may come athwart us, to some Hampstead patient or other? Come, now I am ready. Come, I say! [Takes Sir Marvel's hand, who goes a step or two, and then stops.] Why d'ye stop, child—go you must and shall, so loitering will have no effect, but to make me angry. Come, I say—nay, if you will be pull'd, you shall be pull'd [Pulls and pushes him]. Zounds! you are strong, Bell; I have heard that the Cornish girls can wrestle, and I fancy you have practis'd the sport. Nay, if you are for that, Miss—here, David, come and help pull this young lady into the chaise.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: [Pulling] Cot a mercy, Sir! I can't make hur stir a petty-toe.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Give her a pinch on the arm.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Zounds! let me alone—I will not go, by Jupiter!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: [Flying off] What is it, Sir—it must be the tevil in a planket.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
[surpris'd.] What is it? why, a great country hoyden—they'll swear and romp at home, like
fifty grenadiers, and when they come to town, they mince their words, and mince their steps, as though they could utter nothing but monosyllables, or step above two inches. Come, we'll have t'other tug, Miss—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Will you? [Raises the hood, and looks, first at one, then at the other]. Now, Mr. Evergreen, we'll have a tug, or a wrestle, or what you please.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, that devil Miss Archer! this must be her contrivance—Where are they, where are they?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Where? why, they are in the mode, that's all—emigrating. No, you don't pass this streight—you don't indeed; I'll defend it as the Africans did Thermopylae.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: You, Sir! how dare you take this liberty in my house?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Come, Sir, don't be obstreperous: if you are, I'll clothe you in the riding-hood, and cram you into the post-chaise, as you would have done me; you won't play the Cornish romp as manfully as I did.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Sir, this insolence—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Nay, if you will have a tug, you shall have a tug— [Scuffle to get on the cloak, Evergreen gets off at last]. Here, then, I remain conqueror; but whether the game is Olympic, Isthmian, or Irish, I know not. But Lady Beauville!—to be enroll'd in her suit, and in the Mennil hunt, is all that remains to establish me—fate can do no more! Miss Archer will now be a friend indeed! Oh, Pylades, as Juvenal says, what's life without a friend?—its a dumpling without egg.

div2.head: SCENE, CARLTON's Lodgings.
div2.stage: Enter MISS ARCHER and ARABELLA, followed by a Maid.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Tell Mrs. Tomson, pray, that I am here. Come, cheer up my love; now we are safe;—that dear Sir Marvel has obliged me for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: My dear young lady!—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: My good Mrs. Tomson, this lady wishes to have an apartment here for a few days—Can you accommodate her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I congratulate you, Miss Melville; you will be here perfectly at ease.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Not unless you give some charge about Mr. Evergreen. The dread of seeing him will keep me in perpetual disquiet.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: You know my Guardian—On no pretence admit him, whilst Miss Melville is in your house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: I shall take care, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Then adieu! I must hurry back instantly, lest he should send to watch the carriage;—but you shall see me again in half an hour.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! I am so sorry that you must leave me! I love you already better than any body, except—I mean, I love you better than every body.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I comprehend ye, my Love—adieu!

div2.stage: [Goes with her to the wing. CARLTON enters.]

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Angels! and ministers of grace! Miss Archer!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Mr. Carlton!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aside.] Come to seek me in my lodgings! By Heaven, this is too much! Oh, oh, now then one knows how to catch a coquette. How charm'd I am to see you.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: How could you think of following me here, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aside.] That's well put. Follow you here! I'd follow ye all over the globe. Now don't put on that cold look—It neither becomes the face nor the occasion.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aside.] His familiarity mortifies me even more than his satire. How can you have the presumption, Sir—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Madam, on some occasions not to have presumption would be ungrateful.—I should really be ashamed if at this moment I did not give you reason to believe that I have as much presumption as any unmarried gentleman in town.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Intolerable! Why do you take such liberties with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Why do you take such liberties with me? You have taken the liberty to intrude yourself into my thoughts without my desiring it; you have taken the liberty to obtrude yourself on my dreams—sleeping or waking, I am never free from you. If I mean to be civil to another woman, your image pops itself before me, and steals the compliment for which she was preparing her smiles—Talk of liberties, indeed!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
How dares he treat me thus? The
object of his satire in public, and of his jests in private!—I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Bend your eyes on me, sweet creature, that I may interpret them.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: If by bending them on you, I could convey to you the sentiments with which you have inspired me, you should have their most pointed glances.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aside.] "The sentiments I have inspired!" Now, that, spoken in this apartment, must be taken as the beginning of a declaration—and it would be scandalous to be behind-hand. I assure you, Madam, I am extremely grateful to those sentiments, and beg to assure you, that mine for you are exactly what the most charming woman in the world ought to suppose them.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I don't know what I ought to suppose, Sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You ought to suppose that you are lovely, and that I have eyes:—you ought to suppose that you have a charming spirit, and that I have a heart:—you ought to suppose that you are captivating, and that I am your slave. Now how the devil have I been drawn in to make this ruinous confession?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: There is an air of sincerity about you at this moment, that almost convinces me you do not deceive me; and I rejoice in it. I would have you love me, I would have you adore me—that your punishment may be severe; for if I could think on you with any sentiments but those of contempt, I should despise myself.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
I congratulate ye, Mr. Carlton—I congratulate ye! Fallen into the very snare that, with all thy
boasted knowledge of the sex, thou hast laboured to avoid—trusted a coquette with thy passion, without first being assured that thou hadst touch'd her heart. But who could have doubted, after a visit at my lodgings?—Pshaw! [striking his forehead] 'twas clearly to draw me in;—she penetrated my design, and determined to shew me a poor, ridiculous, miserable plotter. Well, I love her the better for that! Now will it be impossible for that Hyaena to do any one thing, for me or against me, but I shall love her the better for it. And how shall I be used?—worse than a dog! But I'll have thee—Yes, by Heaven! thou dear, proud, bewitching slut, I'll have thee, spite of every artifice that coquetry and female sweetness can devise▪—'Faith, I'll go and tell her so now, in the very teeth of her malice.

div2.head: SCENE, EVERGREEN's.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Don't make me mad—don't make me mad! I tell you I know no more where the girl is than you do.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Not know where she is? Heaven! what can this mean? Did not I leave her under your protecting roof? Did not you assure me—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [Interrupting] Assure ye! what the devil signifies assurances, when the will of a woman is concerned? How could I guess that she'd run away from my protecting roof?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This cannot satisfy me, Sir; you have an air of being angry at my enquiries, rather than sorry for the occasion of them.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Angry! so I am; d—d angry. Why, she has run from me not from you. Who cares about your concern?—What business have you with her?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye; now here he is staring—now we must have explanations. Why, then, in three words, your Bell is my Bell;—you carried her off to prevent her marriage with Lord Penmanmawr, and brought her to the house of Mr. Evergreen, who is Lord Penmanmawr.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye—what you can't comprehend yet?—all stare and wonder!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You that old Lord to whom my Arabella was to have been sacrificed!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye—and you, to expedite the sacrifice, brought her to the altar.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Is it possible? What, throw my dove into the talons of the hawk!—bring the lovely creature to the very house she meant to fly from!—Oh, fool, fool! [Traversing the stage impatiently.] Now then, old gentleman, I am to consider you as my rival—every other tie is dissolved; and as my rival, I insist on your revealing where you have hid the lady?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Don't challenge me—don't think of challenging me, you blood-thirsty wretch—I will not be challenged. 'Tis time some scheme were hit upon to save men of fortune from you duelling blades—We ought to be allowed to fight by proxy, as the militia do—I'd subscribe an hundred guineas towards the corps, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I don't wish to challenge you, Sir; I am no
duelist, but I must know where my Arabella is—I will kneel at your feet if——

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Tell you where she is? I swear by the honour of an ancient Briton I do not know; and if I did know, I would not inform you—Tell you where my Arabella is!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am frozen—Why did she fly? Did she not know that—But why do I stay questioning, when I ought to seek her?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Nay, if you are for that, I'll seek her too—perhaps luck may for once favour sixty, instead of six and twenty; and if I catch her, youngster, I shall mind your ohs and ahs no more than the winds upon Snowdon—He won't challenge me, I believe.

div2.stage: BELLAIR re-enters, stealing in, as though fearful of being seen by EVERGREEN.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I cannot believe but that she is yet in this house—She could not surely fly from it; for, with her extreme inexperience, this town must appear a great gulph to her, in which her innocence would every moment be in danger of being lost. [Looking about.] Carlton's Miss Archer lives here—if I could find her she might give me some insight. None of the servants about? [Looking through the wing.]—No one of whom I can enquire?—Shall I venture to look into the apartments?

div2.stage: Enter FEELOVE, speaking, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Just gone out! Well, when he returns give him these parchments—they may do for his taylor—it is the only way to make them useful now.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Hah! Mr. Bellair—where have you been all the morning? Have you found my niece? The vile story I told you of, has got air—Have you heard of my niece, I say?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Heard of her! why, Sir, she was in this house—she slept here last night.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: In this house!—slept in the house of Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Assuredly; and has been spirited away this morning.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: You should as soon make me believe she slept in the palace of the Grand Turk.—She in this house!—You may as well say she is gone to breakfast in the moon, and turn'd lunatic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What obstinacy! Why, Sir, I tell you that I myself—I say, Sir, that I—I have enquir'd, and I have been assured—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, poor young gentleman! say no more—say no more. Perverseness and folly came in with the frost, I believe, and pinches both old and young.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What steps can we take?—My anxiety for the sweet young creature you have described to me—Pho! what does this trifling fellow do here?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
Hah, Mr. Bellair! they told me you were above, so I would come up. Very unlucky Miss Archer is not at home! she promis'd to introduce me to Lady Beauville—I hear she has a grand route to-morrow, and I want to know her before, that I may be
invited—But I guess where Miss Archer is, so I'll fly after her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Stay, Sir Marvel,—do you know where Miss Archer is?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I guess—I guess. She used my carriage this morning, to run away with one Miss Melville, whom Mr. Evergreen was going to carry into the country.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Heavens! my dear Sir Marvel, you give us life—Now, Doctor, what think ye of her breakfast in the moon?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Faith, I begin to suspect that I may have breakfasted there—I'm sure my brain seems very cloudy. But where are they, Sir—where are they?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I can't tell, 'till I ask my servants; but they can certainly tell where they carried them,—and that puts me in mind of a fine anecdote. About four centuries ago—
sp.stage: [with the air of beginning a long story.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir Marvel, don't keep us here whole centuries—we must know instantly where those ladies are.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Well, well, you shall;—I was only going to tell you, for you know you are not well read, Mr. Bellair, that Queen Dido of Carthagena—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, Doctor, prescribe for him; he is moonstruck too, depend on't. Sir, you must take us directly to the house where your carriage left the ladies.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pray do, good Sir, and then if you want blistering, or bleeding—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I want blistering! no, I am never ill, unless I'm near a physician. Well, come, I will take you, if you'll promise to have Queen Dido afterwards.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, every Queen in the Aeneid, with all my soul. Come along!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pray take me too, and then I'll take the Princesses, and their maids of honour into the bargain.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'll take ye both—I'll take ye both. [Going out last.] What a happy thing it is to be of consequence!

div2.head: SCENE, CARLTON's Lodgings.
div2.stage: Enter Miss ARCHER, followed by Mrs. TOMSON.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I am much concerned that Miss Melville has been indisposed. Do you think she is now asleep?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: I fancy so, Ma'am, for I left her on the sopha—but I'll tell her—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, on no account! let the sweet girl repose a little;—her spirits, I am sure, are much fatigued. If you'll give me that pamphlet I'll amuse myself with it 'till she wakes.

div2.stage: [Mrs. TOMSON presents a pamphlet and goes out. Miss ARCHER tumbles over the leaves a short time.]

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
Well, now, what signifies my attempting to read? my thoughts are so deranged, that Greek would be as pleasant to me as Don Quixote. What a peculiar fate is mine! to receive a declaration of love from the only man whose lips I ever wish'd to hear it from, and yet, to be convey'd in such a way, as to give me more pain than pleasure. The air of sincerity with which he made it, would have transported
me, had it not been poison'd by an unaccountable boldness and freedom.

div2.stage: [Walks towards the book-case, and takes a book—CARLTON enters without seeing her—Throws himself on a chair, and his hat on a table—sees her suddenly.]

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Zounds! Miss Archer here again! Nay, then she's my own—it would be ridiculous to affect displeasure now. [Goes towards her, then stops.] No, faith—she shall speak first;—I'll be courted this time.
sp.stage: [Sits down again; Miss ARCHER not observing him, he begins to sing, to catch her attention.]
sp.p: "I've kiss'd and I've prattled
"With fifty fair maids"—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: [Screams.] This is beyond all bearing!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It would, indeed, if I suffered you to go;—No, no, dear creature! we shan't part now as we did in the morning:—I have just been at your guardian's, to tell you that I forgive all your ill behaviour to-day.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Forgive!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Aye, you may well wonder—'tis more than one in ten would do. Come, come—lower the scorn of that brow, and hear reason.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: I'll hear nothing, Sir, and I insist on your leaving this house instantly.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—that's unreasonable, considering where you are. But, come! I'll allow you half a dozen ill-humoured things, and then you shall attend to me.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
[Seeming to bite her tongue with vexation.] I will have my my own way in something—I
won't say one ill-humour'd thing, though I feel a thousand.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A thousand! Well, we have time before us, charmer; you shall have opportunities enough—every morning at breafast—every day at dinner—every—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: What can the monster mean?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Mean! why to marry you, Petulance! to give you a right to plague me for ever. What an acquisition, for a woman of spirit! Oh, I feel already the horrors of my future fate, but I am resolv'd to go through it—I will go through it!

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: You imagine that the whimsicalness of this must excuse its freedom, Mr. Carlton, but be assured—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pho, pho, don't let us waste time;—the plain English of our situation is this;—you are a coquette, and I am a man of the world; you would like to make me act like a fool, and I am determined to make you act like a woman of sense—a proof that I am the best Christian.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—very well!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I admired you, the first moment I beheld you, but resolv'd not to be made a dangler—which, if I had approach'd you in the common modes of courtship, would have inevitably followed.—I, therefore, took the road you have seen, and in consequence you'll condescend to be happy, and make happy, a year or two sooner than your coquetry would have allow'd.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: To be happy, and make happy!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
Yes; and that in spite of all those pretty affected airs—they are but affected, charmer, you know,
for, at this moment, you feel that I have a kind of resistless impudence about me, which you love for its novelty.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: If I thought it possible, Sir—The wretch reads my very heart.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, nothing but a wish to convince me of it, could bring you to my lodgings; you see the effects of carrying airs too far. You used me in the morning with such barbarity, that your heart, hard as it is, was smote with the reflection, and then you run after me again to make it up. Oh, you dear commiserating—

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: How dare you, Sir, insinuate such horrid things? Run after you!—seek you in your lodgings!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh dear! how a coquette may carry things!

div2.stage: Enter hastily Sir MARVEL, BELLAIR, and FEELOVE.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, oh, here they are! I am come to claim your promise—you must introduce me to Lady Beauville before to-morrow. Not to be at her route, would be to be and not to be—as Kemble says. Pray Ma'am have you seen Kemble?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where, Madam—where is Miss Melville?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Where is my niece?—where is Arabella Melville?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Heyday! What is all this?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Carlton! how little did I suspect that your lodgings—but there she is!—
sp.stage: [Darting through the wing, followed by FEELOVE.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Are these Mr. Carlton's lodgings, then? 'Tis well his boldness has such an excuse.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is it possible that you did not know it?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Know it! Heaven and earth! how can you dare think that I did? I came to visit Miss Melville, whom I attended here this morning, without the most distant idea, that—Bless me! what an imputation has the interest I took in her welfare, subjected me to? I shall never cease to regret the occasion.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nor I to bless it. How many tedious long months of hopes and fears, caprices and coquetry, have I been saved by it?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you are agreed! see the effect of a few good stanzas—'twas my poetry, Madam, not his, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: What poetry?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, that little jeu d' esprit, you know, which was publish'd yesterday, about you.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: What! was not that Mr. Carlton's.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: No; he beg'd to pass for the author, but it was my own composition entirely; without the assistance of any mortal man, whatever—deny it, Mr. Carlton, if you can.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: So those wretched lines were yours? It was you who chose to represent me to the public in so odious and hateful a light!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You had better have been quiet, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, this is dev'lish odd! when they passed for yours, she never said one word against them; and now they are mine, they are wretched, and odious, and hateful!

Heyday! Miss Archer in Mr. Carlton's lodgings!
what, my dear creature, you are afraid of another fatire, and so are come to deprecate his wrath?

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: No, indeed, my dear creature,—but pray what brought you to Mr. Carlton's lodgings?

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Business, Ma'am, I assure you. Pray, Sir, step this way, [to CARLTON.] Here are the verses which you promis'd to get into the news-paper for me.—I have spent this whole day in polishing them.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Madam, Sir Marvel has much more interest that way than I have.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I'll get 'em in—I'll get 'em in, never fear. Let me see. [She endeavours to snatch them.] "Description of Sir Marvel Mushroom, or the Cripplegate Knight." What, Madam, me!—me!—am I a subject for a news-paper?

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: Yes;—or for a comedy, if I could write one. You are rich in folly, Sir Marvel, and would be a treasure to the public.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, Madam, you will not dare—you will not dare. Oh, the license given to these d—d newspapers! I'll get a seat in parliament, in order to vote against the freedom of the press.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: So would all those wretches feel, who tear the minds of the inoffensive or the worthy—were they to be stretched on the rack, to which they so unfeelingly devote others.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My charming creature, you must forgive Sir Marvel—I promised him that you should.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER
sp.p: [smiling]. Secure first your own forgiveness.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: That sweet smile secures it to me.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p:
No; you must earn it by long and
faithful services. I will be a tyrant for two whole years, and you shall be the most humble and devoted of my slaves:—My caprice you shall allow to be reason, and my whims shall be your law.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: For two months agreed! but not one hour longer. [Enter BELLAIR and ARABELLA.]—My dear Bellair, is this angel yours?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mine; and by a whimsical concurrence concealed in your lodgings. How much, Miss Archer, am I indebted to you!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Indebted to her! No, 'tis to me. I wore the cloak, and I was pinch'd and pull'd whilst she escaped. One can neither have credit from one's verses or one's good nature.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: So you really have forgiven him—Did I not foretell?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, goodness! there was nothing to forgive—You can't think how innocent he is.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: The devil! What, Bellair found her first! Come, Sir, give up my Bell!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Your Bell! No, no, you must go for your bell to another steeple, my old friend—This little silver-toned thing would never be heard on the Welch mountains; and so I have given it to him.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: To him! You must joke, Doctor. You cannot mean to bestow your niece on a poor wretch, the victim, as you have often called him, of atrophy and disease.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: There, d'ye see!—again!—again! Sir, you libel me, and, Sir—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Libel ye! Why you libel yourself.—That's your poor invalid—the dying man. You'll never be able to stand the laugh, if you give your niece to him. Come, come, Doctor, give me the—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir I have received Miss Melville from this gentleman, who will be so generous as to pardon the innocent stratagems of love.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Stratagems! What then—what then, are you the—the—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You know I told you, Doctor, that I had an irresistable fancy, that I should live and become a stout, hale young fellow. I determined not to oppose my odd fancy, as the old lady did her's.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE
sp.p: Ho—h! So, Sir, you had the—the impudence—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I had the impudence to live—But pray pardon it! I will do any thing but die—I'll swallow all the gums, woods, herbs, and funguses, in your medicopeia, to make it up.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: You had better, Sir—I say, you had better—Oh!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Stay, good Sir! you must be reconciled.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Dear Doctor, be but reconciled, I'll advertise my death, change my name, and fight every man who dares tell me I am alive.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: He must not be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: He can't resist us.—I'll make love to him. Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: And I'll let him prescribe for me—Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: Miss JUV.
sp.p: And I'll write the epithalamium—Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: He shall resist you—He shall not be reconciled.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Say you so? Here, Mr. Bellair [giving his hand] I will be reconciled, though—excuse me!—I should rather you were dead.—However, I will be reconciled.

sp.speaker: EVEGR.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you will, will ye? You shall repent it. Bellair, though I shall never speak to you more, I'll tell you at parting that her fortune is thirty thousand pounds—Remember, thirty. There, Doctor, that has cut you short of ten or fifteen thousand, I know; so your joke has cost as much as mine.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, you are—Sir, my resentment for this usage—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, gentlemen, you must not—you must not quarrel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, yes, let 'em quarrel, pray, if they have a fancy for it. Doctor, I'll carry your challenge—What are your weapons?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: His prescriptions—He can kill with nothing else; he's harmless in all other respects.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: And you are harmless in nothing but your wit;—the point of that is never felt.

sp.speaker: Miss ARCHER.
sp.p: Come, come, since your anger expends itself in words, there are hopes of its subsiding; and that the happiness we are preparing to enjoy, will neither be clouded by your displeasure; nor by that of our best friends.
sp.l: To them we bend, submissive to their laws,

lg.l: I SPEAK the Epilogue! Lud, how they teaze one!
They write so dull—so—seldom they can please one:
I never read 'em—Well—I'll trust to chance,
And now before 'em, frighten'd, I'll advance.
Ladies and Gents—behold—that is—our play
We hope will—Lud, I don't know what to say!
To entertain the cit, the belle, the beau,
With India—Stamps—or, Race at Fontainbleau.
In days of yore—bright days, with conquest crown'd!
The French we beat, and beat on their own ground;
We conquer still by valour or by cunning,
On their own ground we beat'em now—in running.
I'll try, as Mercury did, a small deception,
It may secure, at least, a good reception.—
How do I look? If I can trust my glass,
I think for Venus I may safely pass;
(I'm sure found out to say I'm any other;)
No more Miss Archer now—the archer's mother!
Nay, never wonder, doubt, nor start, nor stare,
Don't you perceive the Goddess in my air?
Yon low'ring brow says, No—Well!—if you doubt me,
I'll drop the Goddess,—here's enough without me:
Each scarlet Mars above, though e'er so dainty,
May leer around—there's Venus's in plenty;
Or aim his glass beneath, upon the pit,
He'll see his Venus by her Vulcan sit:
There Bacchus woos his Venus all divine!
He nectar asks—but she—a pint of wine!
And you can never want the Queen of Love,
I speak to you, ye roaring Gods above;—
Momus is surely there, from all this racket,
Yonder he sits—he's in a sailor's jacket;
Thrice happy God, who lives but in a joke!
His Venus laughs, too—in her hat and cloak.
Where have I got to?—Lud, how glib my tongue!
Am I Miss Archer, Venus, or Miss Younge?
Be what I will, among my friends I rank ye,
Applaud Miss Archer, and Miss Younge shall thank ye.
